ba3f2c88748d4e89ba5bcc06c398ff48_fiction.question: What is the main theme of "On Canaan's Side" by Sebastian Barry?
ba3f2c88748d4e89ba5bcc06c398ff48_fiction.answer: The main focus of "On Canaan's Side" by Sebastian Barry is the deep examination of grief and loss, placed within a context of personal and historical upheaval.The main character, Lilly Bere, explores her memories and feelings following a tragedy, emphasizing how grief can permeate and change a person's life.This theme is expressed through Lilly's thoughts on her connections and the lingering heaviness of her losses, as she contends with her isolation and the effects of those she has cherished and lost.The story further explores the intricacies of memory, demonstrating how earlier experiences influence current emotions and identities, especially regarding themes of displacement and abandonment.In summary, the novel captures the spirit of resilience in the face of sorrow, illustrating the challenge of coming to terms with both individual experiences and the larger societal shifts that shape them.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The ground of the cathedral was flagged and hard. Her beautiful dress could not save her, and her perfect face hit the stone and smashed worse than an egg. My heart broke for her in the same instance, so that the sound of her destruction became in my childish memory the sound of my heart breaking. And even though it was a babyish fancy, I do wonder now if it might not be a sound like that an eighty-nine-year-old heart makes, coming asunder from grief – a small, slight sound.

But the feeling of it is like a landscape engulfed in floodwater in the pitch darkness, and everything, hearth and byre, animal and human, terrified and threatened. It is as if someone, some great agency, some CIA of the heavens, knew well the little mechanism that I am, and how it is wrapped and fixed, and has the booklet or manual to undo me, and cog by cog and wire by wire is doing so, with no intention ever to put me back together again, and indifferent to the fact that all my pieces are being thrown down and lost. I am so terrified by grief that there is solace in nothing.

I am so terrified by grief that there is solace in nothing.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
How he had heard a German soldier singing, and had sung back to him across no man's land, only to receive the bullet of a sniper.

'Just like Willie,' my father said, in equal simplicity. 'Always singing.'

I knew even at sixteen that Willie after three years of war had been hollowed out by horror and extinction, and my father maybe knew that too, so that the solace of the sergeant's letter, describing Willie dying in a moment of generosity and ease, did not have a measure.

faithfulness_original_text.text: 'Is everything good here?' she said. I feared we were to have the funeral conversation after all, and my heart sank. I had been so grateful to her for not saying anything, knowing full well it was uppermost on her mind. She who had waded through the fires of grief many times had usually infinite discretion.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Tadg gave a laugh then in the cobbled street. It was going to be quite dark soon, except just as I thought that, the lamps started to light one by one, in a miraculous sequence. Were they singing, those lamps, did they make a tiny noise for themselves? It wasn't that I was a woman and scared, it was that I was a human being and scared. The future, the following day, was as dark as the high sky, and suddenly what I had lost bore in on me, my father, stern and strange as he was, and my sisters, one a hunched unmarriageable girl, and the other a nervous, touchy person soon to be a similar bride – funny how I suddenly saw them like that, whereas before they had just been my eternal sisters – even the loss of poor Willie, that in some way had brought me here to this desolate, angry street in New York, all pushed through me like a flooded mountain stream through previously secure whinbushes, pulling at their tremendous roots, assaulting their safety, and I quailed there, in the street, and shook, my travelling coat failing to keep me warm suddenly, my legs failing me.

faithfulness_original_text.text: So I was obliged to enter her house in quietness, and reach my little wooden room, shut fast the door, and pant there on the bare boards, not in the least knowing what to do. I think it was the first time in my life I was actually alone, without prospect of seeing another soul who would want to assist me. I felt standing there as if my life had been indeed rescinded, as if indeed some strange cancellation had taken place in some hall of heaven, and I was now to be dispensed with in some ruthless dispensation. I wondered and wondered should I have stayed where I was, at Tadg's side? Would the American police not have helped me, in some way I could not articulate or fathom? I knew Tadg was gone, his sentence of death carried out it would seem, even across the four thousand miles of the Atlantic Ocean. I presumed my own murder was hotly plotted and would follow, but in truth I could not imagine what would happen in my story now as I bumped up against this new state of being alone, of facing what was to come, alone.

faithfulness_original_text.text: The thought of leaving Tadg's bag there troubled me more than you would think it would. But it was like a proof that he would not be coming with me. His few shirts and his spare trousers also to be abandoned. It felt like I was betraying him somehow, leaving his things was an accusation that I had been unable to save him, to keep him in the story of life.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
_ That's some old poem or ballad, I forget which.

I seem to remember some matters well enough, even in the great mire that is my poor head, but it would give me a great fright to have to put a date on everything. Thank God it does not behove me to do so. For it is just me sitting here, telling my tale to myself, that's what it feels like, mostly, old matters held in the fingers of memory, like those old beads in a family rosary, polished by a lifetime of prayers, and handed down, and slowly slowly no doubt diminishing and thinning as they go from creature to creature.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Something other than the dark was convening beyond the kitchen, marking the darkening window glass, was it even an army of the fog, legions upon legions rising up from the surface of the sea, exhausted soldiers finding again their strength, their fabled lives, and coming onto the beach of Bridgehampton, to take it in a rightful conquest? I did not know. I felt I would never know anything again, I was not in any way dismayed by the feeling. I was absolutely in cahoots with that moment, because contained in it I sensed both my disappearance and my queer victory. I carried Bill in my breast, and now instead of it being a stony weight that would kill me, crush the last breath from me, it was something else again entirely, a lightness, a veritable possession, as if I was a little cart for him, to carry his lightest of souls into heaven.

e3f282d95de2455db2c1c5c5dff02158_fiction.question: What is the primary conflict in "Hurrah for Capt. Early" and what is the way it gets resolved?
e3f282d95de2455db2c1c5c5dff02158_fiction.answer: The central conflict in "Hurrah for Capt."Early" focuses on a clash between Captain Early and a character called Macon.Macon mocks Captain Early, suggesting he ought to draw his pistol rather than depend on his saber.The resolution takes place when Captain Early demonstrates his authority by positioning his saber against Macon's breastbone, signifying that he is ready to protect himself with a blade instead of a gun.This act of intimidation successfully diffuses the situation, enabling Early to steer clear of a direct physical confrontation.

Irritated. Drunk, too, his eyes not focusing as they should. Now he was looking over his shoulder at the Circle-Eye riders, maybe wanting them to tell him what to do.

One of them, not Wayman but one of the others, called out, "You got your forty-four in your hand, ain't you? What're you waiting on?"

Catlett raised the saber to lay the tip against Macon's breastbone, saying to him, "You use your pistol and I use steel? All right, if that's how you want it.

One of them, not Wayman but one of the others, called out, "You got your forty-four in your hand, ain't you? What're you waiting on?"

Catlett raised the saber to lay the tip against Macon's breastbone, saying to him, "You use your pistol and I use steel? All right, if that's how you want it.

83565310801d492a913bc4aba2b89f76_fiction.question: How does the main character characterize their sister Ariel?
83565310801d492a913bc4aba2b89f76_fiction.answer: The main character portrays their sister Ariel as an attractive girl who has their mother's auburn hair and soft blue eyes, combined with their father's calm and thoughtful personality.Ariel is depicted as the family's "golden child," endowed with musical abilities that enchant everyone nearby, as shown during a performance when she received applause with a glistening tear of joy in her eyes.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Except for me Jake didn't have friends and I wasn't sure the weight I should give the confession or the response I should offer.

"Hey, you two desperadoes."

My sister stood leaning against the doorframe with her arms crossed and a wry smile on her lips. Ariel was a pretty girl. She had my mother's auburn hair and pillowy blue eyes and my father's quiet and considered countenance.
anchor: Ariel was a pretty girl.
She had my mother's auburn hair and pillowy blue eyes and my father's quiet and considered countenance.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"

"It doesn't matter," she said.

But I could tell that it did.

Ariel was my parents' golden child. She had a quick mind and the gift of easy charm and her fingers possessed magic on the keyboard and we knew, all of us who loved her, that she was destined for greatness.
anchor: She had a quick mind and the gift of easy charm and her fingers possessed magic on the keyboard and we knew, all of us who loved her, that she was destined for greatness.

faithfulness_original_text.text: It haunted me. Not Ariel's death itself which was still a mystery but her rising from the river in the hands of my father and the other men and her repose as I envisioned it on the clean soft bed of a satin-lined coffin at van der Waal's. I didn't know then in the way I do now the details of death in a river, of a body submerged for three days, of the desecration of the flesh that occurs during an autopsy, and I will not tell you these things. I imagined Ariel as I'd last seen her, beautiful in her red dress with her long auburn hair brushed silky and held back with the mother-of-pearl barrette and about her throat a gold necklace with a heart-shaped locket and on her wrist a gold watch and in her eyes a tearful sheen of happiness as she accepted the applause for her music that Fourth of July night at Luther Park.

d147f497df774e69999f1d22512580b2_fiction.question: What does the story communicate regarding the essence of home and belonging?
d147f497df774e69999f1d22512580b2_fiction.answer: The narrative highlights that home and belonging are intricate and highly individual ideas that might not align with traditional definitions.It indicates that genuine belonging is discovered in environments and connections that align with an individual's identity and experiences, instead of conventional standards of family or society.For example, one character contemplates the deep connection they experience in a location that stretches across realities to embrace them as part of itself, implying a special relationship that goes beyond conventional ideas of home.Furthermore, the significance of companionship and mutual understanding among peers emphasizes that a sense of belonging can be discovered in communities that affirm one's uniqueness, providing comfort even when returning to a conventional home is not an option.In the end, the story communicates that the core of home is found in connection, acceptance, and the acknowledgment of one's authentic self.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
About one out of every three potential students slipped through her fingers, and she mourned for them, those whose lives would be so much harder than they needed to be, when they could have been saved. But she rejoiced for those who were given to her care. At least while they were with her, they would be with someone who understood. Even if they would never have the opportunity to go back home, they would have someone who understood, and the company of their peers, which was a treasure beyond reckoning.

Eleanor West spent her days giving them what she had never had, and hoped that someday, it would be enough to pay her passage back to the place where she belonged.
anchor: Even if they would never have the opportunity to go back home, they would have someone who understood, and the company of their peers, which was a treasure beyond reckoning.
Eleanor West spent her days giving them what she had never had, and hoped that someday, it would be enough to pay her passage back to the place where she belonged.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"I'm crying because I'm angry, and I'm sad, and I want to go home."

"Stupid girl," said Sumi. She placed a sympathetic hand atop Nancy's head before smacking her—lightly, but still a hit—and leaping up onto her bed, crouching next to the open suitcase. "You don't mean home where your parents are, do you? Home to school and class and boys and blather, no, no, no, not for you anymore, all those things are for other people, people who aren't as special as you are.
anchor: "You don't mean home where your parents are, do you? Home to school and class and boys and blather, no, no, no, not for you anymore, all those things are for other people, people who aren't as special as you are.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"

"Going back" had two distinct meanings at the school, depending on how it was said. It was the best thing in the world. It was also the worst thing that could happen to anybody. It was returning to a place that understood you so well that it had reached across realities to find you, claiming you as its own and only; it was being sent to a family that wanted to love you, wanted to keep you safe and sound, but didn't know you well enough to do anything but hurt you.
anchor: It was returning to a place that understood you so well that it had reached across realities to find you, claiming you as its own and only; it was being sent to a family that wanted to love you, wanted to keep you safe and sound, but didn't know you well enough to do anything but hurt you.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
She watched him walk away. When the door shut behind him, she closed her eyes and allowed herself a few seconds of stillness, centering her thoughts.

So this was the world. This was the place she'd come from—and more, this was the place where she came closest to belonging in this world.

356adfdf9feb4629af007dfd4b20c71c_fiction.question: In what ways does Danny Rossi's composition for the ballet "Arcadia" mirror his personal conflicts?
356adfdf9feb4629af007dfd4b20c71c_fiction.answer: Danny Rossi's score for the ballet "Arcadia" acts as a deeply expressive reflection of his personal conflicts, especially his unreturned affection for Maria Pastore and his doubts about his musical ability.His self-assessment of his work as "second-rate" and "derivative" emphasizes a profound sense of inadequacy and adds to the emotional intricacy of the ballet, reflecting his fears and aspirations through the music he composes.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"

"I'm aware of that," Weisman replied softly.

"But you don't get my point," Danny retorted. "I'm not that brilliant a conductor. And at best my composing is second-rate, derivative.

c6d884cd9da04754a43e62006e1e98aa_fiction.question: Can you explain the event related to the missing illustrations for Gregory Maybrick's book about the Guy Fawkes conspiracy?
c6d884cd9da04754a43e62006e1e98aa_fiction.answer: The artwork for Gregory Maybrick's book about the Guy Fawkes conspiracy disappeared amid a time of chaos.Specifically, they went missing from James de Witt's office while he was engaged with other matters, such as a meeting with an author in Brighton.Nevertheless, the illustrations were ultimately found in the exact spot where de Witt had initially stored them, suggesting that they might have been intentionally hidden prior to their return.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
" He paused then said: "Unless of course she was the one responsible."

She didn't miss the sudden note of hope in his voice. So he was more worried than he would admit. She said bitterly: "That would be a neat way out of our troubles, wouldn't it? But how could she have been, Gerard? She was off sick, remember, when the Stilgoe proofs were tampered with and visiting an author in Brighton when we lost the illustrations for the Guy Fawkes book.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"

"Did the stuff ever come to light?"

"Not until too late. There were doubts whether Maybrick would want to publish at all but the book was in the catalogue and it was decided to go ahead with alternative illustrations and some necessary changes to the text. A week after they'd finished printing, the envelope and its contents mysteriously reappeared. De Witt found it in his cupboard, exactly where he had placed it.

cfe69a520c564332a8362a0aac4268cc_fiction.question: What effect does the narrator's choice to include Ava in the film project have?
cfe69a520c564332a8362a0aac4268cc_fiction.answer: The narrator's choice to include Ava in the film project greatly influences their personal relationship, as it not only deepens their bond but also offers Ava a chance to demonstrate her talents on a broader stage.This participation might expose her to the realms of acting and filmmaking, possibly kickstarting her career and broadening her opportunities within the industry.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Everything we've been planning is coming together. Here she is: Clyde Jones's legacy. And as I watch Ava go through the scene three more times, each time capturing the emotion in a way that I imagine is even better than what Theo and Rebecca are dreaming of, I become more and more sure that we are witnessing something important.

Not only will _Yes & Yes_ be a great film, but it has the potential to introduce the world to Ava Garden Wilder, and Ava Garden Wilder to the world.

b4283eb45679412d958e789b2a40a279_fiction.question: What is the importance of the title "Eastern Standard Tribe"?
b4283eb45679412d958e789b2a40a279_fiction.answer: The title "Eastern Standard Tribe" represents a community built on common temporal experiences rather than physical closeness.It highlights how modern technology influences identity formation, indicating that individuals can associate and connect with peers based on shared traits rather than geographic proximity, such as living in the Eastern Standard Time zone.This demonstrates wider concepts of online communities and social engagement in a digitally interconnected environment.

faithfulness_original_text.text: You go to bed at nine, 'cause that's when they go to bed. Used to be that it was stockbrokers and journos and factory workers who did that kind of thing, but now it's anyone who doesn't fit in. The geniuses and lunatics to whom the local doctrine tastes wrong. They choose their peers based on similarity, not geography, and they keep themselves awake at the same time as them.
anchor: They choose their peers based on similarity, not geography, and they keep themselves awake at the same time as them.

209d8ac4e0a349c5bca06c0b8314b587_fiction.question: What is the importance of the summer during which the story occurs?
209d8ac4e0a349c5bca06c0b8314b587_fiction.answer: The summer carries deep importance as it represents a season characterized by numerous tragic occurrences and fatalities, including the particular case of a child who lost their life due to a train.This vast number of deaths encourages a more profound reflection on loss and its repercussions.The story delves into themes of suffering, recollection, and the hard-won insight that frequently follows such anguish, implying that amid these challenges, people experience the "awful grace of God" that arises from despair.

It was a summer in which death, in visitation, assumed many forms.

61d55d2e71de4c19b97a7d6d61c8acfe_fiction.question: In what way does the protagonist characterize their mother's singing?
61d55d2e71de4c19b97a7d6d61c8acfe_fiction.answer: The protagonist expresses that their mother's singing is a deeply moving experience that merges beauty with emotional depth.Her voice is marked by a deep and measured cadence, inspiring a feeling of tranquility and elevated happiness.The singing is reported to not only touch the heart but also to profoundly impact listeners, stirring emotions that range from joy to love and even inspiring a call to action.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Ariel laid her hands again on the organ keyboard and paused and prepared herself then began to play. And my mother closed her eyes and composed herself to sing.

When my mother sang I almost believed in heaven. It wasn't just that she had a beautiful voice but also that she had a way of delivering a piece that pierced your heart. Oh when she sang she could make a fence post cry. When she sang she could make people laugh or dance or fall in love or go to war.
anchor: It wasn't just that she had a beautiful voice but also that she had a way of delivering a piece that pierced your heart.
When she sang she could make people laugh or dance or fall in love or go to war.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Cole whose roots were in southern Missouri. She'd asked my mother to sing a spiritual, Swing Low, Sweet Chariot.

When my mother finally sang it was not just a hymn she offered, it was consummate comfort. She sang slowly and richly and delivered the heart of that great spiritual as if she was delivering heaven itself and her face was beautiful and full of peace.
anchor: She sang slowly and richly and delivered the heart of that great spiritual as if she was delivering heaven itself and her face was beautiful and full of peace.

f7664d995f0b4693923fbae25e53175c_fiction.question: Who are the primary characters in the book and what are their goals?
f7664d995f0b4693923fbae25e53175c_fiction.answer: The primary figures in the book consist of Barney Livingston, who aims to be a caring and perceptive doctor; Laura Castellano, who hopes to surmount the obstacles encountered by women in medicine to become a doctor; and Bennett Landsmann, a gifted athlete and student exploring his identity and aspirations.These ambitions underscore their personal paths and the challenges they face throughout the process.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"—From _Doctors_

THE CALLING THEY HAVE CHOSEN WILL BREAK SOME OF THEM WHILE IT WILL FORCE OTHERS TO CONFRONT THEIR MOST CLOSELY HELD SECRETS, DREAMS, AND FEARS.

_BARNEY_ —He watched, helpless, as a physician turned his back on his dying father. At that moment. Barney vowed to become a different kind of doctor.

404757fce0204759ba38bad6512e503f_fiction.question: What is the importance of the title "Orbiting Jupiter"?
404757fce0204759ba38bad6512e503f_fiction.answer: The title "Orbiting Jupiter" carries substantial meaning as it represents Joseph's deep emotional journey and his bond with his daughter, Jupiter, whom he has never encountered.The term "orbiting" implies both distance and longing, capturing Joseph's challenges as he manages the difficulties of his life while maintaining hope for reuniting with his daughter.This metaphor of orbiting emphasizes the themes of yearning, family connections, and the pursuit of redemption that run throughout the story.

89cc6e4eb586407caa4ecdad8b006e77_fiction.question: What is the central theme of "Everything Asian" by Sung J. Woo?
89cc6e4eb586407caa4ecdad8b006e77_fiction.answer: The primary theme of "Everything Asian" by Sung J.Woo centers on the difficulties of adaptation encountered by a Korean family as they move to the United States.The story delves into their attempts to adapt to a new cultural environment while working to maintain their own identity.This theme is captured in the family's eagerness to learn and adapt to their new surroundings, as illustrated by the evocative imagery of their arrival and journey in America.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
All he was trying to do was make things better for himself and the rest of us. But did he have to drag the whole family to this thing? Noona and I were doing just fine, learning at school and through television, and Mother couldn't care less. If Father wasn't afraid, wouldn't he just go by himself and leave us in peace?

Who knows. He turned the knob, pushed open the creaky door, and there we stood, a Korean family in America, ready and willing to learn, and impeccably dressed to boot.

5d455b89eac64a05b2ea27aed56b6702_fiction.question: In what ways does the location of Promised Land, South Carolina, influence the characters' viewpoints and relationships?
5d455b89eac64a05b2ea27aed56b6702_fiction.answer: The location of Promised Land, South Carolina, significantly influences the characters' viewpoints and relationships because of its tight-knit, small community.In this community, there is a strong sense of familiarity as everyone is acquainted with each other, resulting in a narrow scope of conversation and limiting personal choices and relationships.The cultural and religious conventions present in this environment additionally shape how individuals perceive themselves and one another, resulting in a situation where personal lives are frequently interconnected and examined within the community framework.This interconnection creates a distinctive atmosphere that can both encourage and limit personal expression, as inhabitants manage their interactions while being observed by those living nearby.

3a1440850e884f67a587ce9e4c5779f0_fiction.question: How does the character In Sook deal with her feelings of loneliness and homesickness after relocating to the United States?
3a1440850e884f67a587ce9e4c5779f0_fiction.answer: In Sook deals with her feelings of loneliness and homesickness following her relocation to the United States by producing tapes containing her voice to share with her friends in Korea, ultimately recording seven and a half hours of messages on her tape recorder.Furthermore, she discovers comfort in playing the piano, which her father buys for her despite their economic hardships, offering her a means of creative expression and a link to her history.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
When Father pressed EJECT, the lid sprang up like a catapult.

Noona put the tape recorder to work immediately. She spoke intensely, her long black hair falling around the unit like a cape, her lips floating over the tiny triple slats on the built-in microphone. The first day, she sat in her room and made five ninety-minute tapes in a row, seven and a half hours of her fragile voice laid out on thin magnetic ribbon.

46b494bc99cf448f8f41a925bfd5f775_fiction.question: What is the central conflict in "Sparks," and how is it connected to Robin Harris's situation?
46b494bc99cf448f8f41a925bfd5f775_fiction.answer: The primary conflict in "Sparks" revolves around the inquiry into a blaze that engulfed Robin Harris's home.Investigator Canavan is confronted with the task of ascertaining whether the fire was accidental or deliberately ignited, which has a direct effect on the insurance claim that Robin is attempting to settle.The tension stems from the uncertainty surrounding the fire's nature and its consequences for Robin's financial circumstances and emotional well-being as she waits for the outcome of her claim.

0d69d5252c4942e4a1849b9475b3f5dd_fiction.question: In what ways did publishing "Riding the Bullet" as an e-book impact Stephen King?
0d69d5252c4942e4a1849b9475b3f5dd_fiction.answer: The release of "Riding the Bullet" as an e-book greatly enhanced Stephen King's visibility, establishing him as a key player in the world of digital publishing.Nevertheless, he conveyed his frustration that readers appeared to be more intrigued by the novelty of the electronic format than by the actual content of the story.This understanding emphasized a gap between the medium and the message for King, influencing his perspectives on digital storytelling and audience involvement.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
If it got you to turn off the TV, as far as I'm concerned, it (or any of the stories in the collection which follows) is a total success.

But in the wake of "Bullet," all the guys in ties wanted to know was, "How's it doing? How's it selling?" How to tell them I didn't give a flying fuck how it was doing in the marketplace, that what I cared about was how it was doing in the reader's heart? Was it succeeding there? Failing? Getting through to the nerve-endings? Causing that little frisson which is the spooky story's raison d'être? I gradually realized that I was seeing another example of creative ebb, another step by another art on the road that may indeed end in extinction. There is something weirdly decadent about appearing on the cover of a major magazine simply because you used an alternate route into the marketplace. There is something weirder about realizing that all those readers might have been a lot more interested in the novelty of the electronic package than they were in what was inside the package.

cbb96c5ccb0c415aaf93dd2fd37e0445_fiction.question: What is Raymond Cruz's initial approach as the homicide lieutenant in the investigation of Judge Guy's murder?
cbb96c5ccb0c415aaf93dd2fd37e0445_fiction.answer: Raymond Cruz begins his investigation of Judge Guy's murder in a methodical manner, as shown by the uniformed evidence technicians who are carefully recording the crime scene.They are photographing, measuring distances, and gathering different types of evidence, including betting ticket stubs and credit cards, while also getting ready to examine the judge's car for fingerprints and additional clues.Even with this systematic method, Cruz also contends with personal emotions and previous experiences that shape his viewpoint on the case.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The squad-car guys didn't know for sure he's dead, so they call EMS. EMS comes, they take one look, call the meat wagon."

Hunter said, "They don't know he's _dead_? He took about three in the mouth, two more in the chest, through and through, big fucking exit wounds—they don't know he's dead."

Uniformed evidence technicians were taking Polaroid shots of the body and the Mark VI, measuring distances, drawing a plan of the scene, picking up betting ticket stubs, credit cards, cigarette butts; they would haul the judge's car to the police garage on Jefferson and go over it for prints, poke around in all its crevices.

2a0ac01748164fa0a18f94069144c479_fiction.question: In what ways does Andrew Eliot's connection with his family affect his experiences at Harvard?
2a0ac01748164fa0a18f94069144c479_fiction.answer: Andrew Eliot's connection with his family significantly influences his experiences at Harvard, molding his sense of ambition and self-identity.He struggles with the burden of his family's esteemed history in the military, which generates a pressure to excel but also a hesitance to emulate their path.This struggle causes him to experience a reduced motivation for conventional success, highlighting a wider conflict between his family's expectations and his personal desires for uniqueness and satisfaction at the university.

# ANDREW ELIOT'S DIARY

March 10, 1959

After graduating I expected to find myself metaphorically, but not literally, at sea.

Yet here I am crossing the Atlantic on a ship of the U. Knowing of my family's distinguished record in this branch of the services, I had been determined not to follow where I might stumble in their footsteps.

I feel such aching sadness that the only solace I can find is staying near the place she died.

Also, I need time to think about what I want to do with the rest of my life. Losing Fanny has changed me a great deal. I seem somehow to feel less of the ambition I once had to go out and become a big "success"—whatever that means.

728cba10bdfc4f2d8e9f749fcd171b73_fiction.question: In what way does the book portray the relationship between Barney Livingston and Laura Castellano?
728cba10bdfc4f2d8e9f749fcd171b73_fiction.answer: The book depicts the connection between Barney Livingston and Laura Castellano as a profound and intricate relationship that has developed over time.Their enduring friendship started in childhood as they grew up together in Brooklyn, implying a bond resembling that of siblings.Although Barney claims that their friendship is platonic, an underlying tension suggests that his true feelings might still be aimed at Laura, complicating the dynamics of their relationship.Moreover, Laura's fervent encouragement for Barney during a pivotal time in his life highlights the depth of their bond, as she is portrayed as his most devoted advocate.In general, their relationship combines aspects of friendship, support, and unvoiced feelings, highlighting the complexities of their connection.

d0b8e01cf21749ffa8d5392396907187_fiction.question: What obstacles does George Hammond encounter when relocating to the Idyll Inn, and what methods does he use to deal with them?
d0b8e01cf21749ffa8d5392396907187_fiction.answer: After relocating to the Idyll Inn, George Hammond faces numerous difficulties due to a stroke that has partially affected him.He faces physical challenges, particularly with his mobility, as he is able to get his right leg to move, albeit with some difficulty, but is unable to do the same with his left leg.This inability causes him to oppose taking his prescribed medications, especially the antidepressants, which could benefit his mental well-being, according to Sylvia, who thinks he should make greater use of them.Moreover, he shows resistance and irritation by requesting help instead of maneuvering his wheelchair on his own, and he further demonstrates his frustration by intentionally throwing his dessert on the floor while articulating his dissatisfaction.In the end, George manages these challenges by taking control of his circumstances, emphasizing a typical yet commendable effort for autonomy in a difficult new setting.

faithfulness_original_text.text: He's a man who, if he can't get what he wants one way, will—except for the store, he finally couldn't save it; or Alice, he couldn't fix her, either—invent another route to his goal and desire. He has a creative nature that way. So he lies on the kitchen floor waiting for capacities to return. He tests this and that and finally gets his right leg to obey him, however reluctantly, but not his left leg.
anchor: He tests this and that and finally gets his right leg to obey him, however reluctantly, but not his left leg.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
By six-thirty, a good half-hour before Sylvia would have even been starting her meal, everyone is gone from the dining room as if, like messy plates and used cutlery, residents are to be cleaned away as smartly as possible. It's early days for a campaign of civil disobedience, but Sylvia has been considering an obdurate, chair-gripping refusal to move. A group sit-in would be wonderfully literal, and bound to be more effective than George's periodic tantrums; the ones that caused Annabel Walker or one of her minions to call Colette to fly here again to get him calmed down because otherwise, despite previous promises, "we might not be able to keep him here after all."

He's been pushing the envelope, that's for sure: gritting his teeth against taking his meds, specifically the prescribed antidepressants, which personally Sylvia thinks he should be taking as many of as he can get; refusing to propel himself in his wheelchair, demanding the services of an aide instead, if good-hearted or too amenable Greta isn't around; plus the last straw, when he deliberately tossed, as opposed to dropped, his lemon cake and custard dessert on the dining-room floor, loudly pronouncing one of the words he can actually say clearly, which is "crap."

His methods may be unfortunate, but Sylvia is basically sympathetic to his aims. It's a matter of power, and trying to exert some control—aside from going about it foolishly, he's putting up a pretty ordinary and admirable struggle.

8075de4d711e40599aabb6346652751d_fiction.question: In what ways does the Idyll Inn serve its residents, and what are the anticipations of its remote investors?
8075de4d711e40599aabb6346652751d_fiction.answer: The Idyll Inn serves its residents by establishing a thorough operational framework that encompasses specific services, menus, staffing levels, recreational activities, and consideration of cultural and religious practices, guaranteeing a holistic living experience.Conversely, investors anticipate consistent and dependable returns, along with the potential for the chain to be purchased by a larger corporation, which would safeguard their financial interests and foster the establishment's development and sustainability.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
There is, too, considerable risk of dented fenders, bumped bumpers, in all the forwarding and reversing and squeezing by large and small cars, many of them occupied by tense multi-generational groups up to their necks and nerve endings in emotions of one sort and another.

How purposefully strangers hustle through the parking lot, how swiftly and surprisingly movers wielding sofas and chairs in the corridors overtake those slowly taking up residence—how alarming and rude.

Never mind, their day will come.

At this stage in the numbered company's expanding history, there's a vast, detailed, operational template governing services, menus, staffing levels, recreational offerings, cultural and religious observances, decor and other fundamental amenities, right down to the number and location of phone connections in individual suites.

b11c19f76ed1425490691ab1e1104b8d_fiction.question: In what ways does Natalie's view of reality change during the course of the novel?
b11c19f76ed1425490691ab1e1104b8d_fiction.answer:
Throughout the novel, Natalie's view of reality changes markedly, highlighting her internal conflict between belonging and alienation.At first, she struggles with her sense of self, perceiving herself as just a "college girl" shaped by outside pressures instead of her authentic identity, while reflecting on her life and societal roles.This conflict causes her to experience moments of self-reflection in which she doubts her reality, considering the possibility that she may not truly be Natalie Waite, but rather someone completely different or even a creation of another's imagination.She starts perceiving the individuals surrounding her as "automatons," emphasizing her feelings of sympathy and disconnection from those who appear to glide through life effortlessly, prompting her to reflect on her own value and the genuineness of her experiences.This leads to an awareness that her perceptions may not be genuine, indicating a more profound psychological struggle as she faces the idea that her existence might merely be a dream, prompting questions about her sanity. 

In the end, her experience symbolizes a significant breakdown of her former idealism, resulting in a more fractured comprehension of her identity and her reality.She grows more conscious of the clash between her ambitions and the harshness of her environment, highlighting a profound reflection on the challenges of identity and being in a restrictive world.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Waite said this morning, and laughed. " _I_ am God," he added.

Natalie Waite, who was seventeen years old but who felt that she had been truly conscious only since she was about fifteen, lived in an odd corner of a world of sound and sight past the daily voices of her father and mother and their incomprehensible actions. For the past two years—since, in fact, she had turned around suddenly one bright morning and seen from the corner of her eye a person called Natalie, existing, charted, inescapably located on a spot of ground, favored with sense and feet and a bright-red sweater, and most obscurely alive—she had lived completely by herself, allowing not even her father access to the farther places of her mind.
anchor: For the past two years—since, in fact, she had turned around suddenly one bright morning and seen from the corner of her eye a person called Natalie, existing, charted, inescapably located on a spot of ground, favored with sense and feet and a bright-red sweater, and most obscurely alive—she had lived completely by herself, allowing not even her father access to the farther places of her mind.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Behind the house, behind even the kitchen garden, Mr. Waite had graciously permitted trees to grow unmolested, and when Natalie was younger, before the garden and the view from the cliff had taken such a hold of her, she had delighted in playing pirate and cowboy and knight in armor among the trees. Now, however, for some reason only remotely connected with knights in armor, the tree on the grass belonged to her, and she ignored the trees below as dark and silent and unprovocative.

The sight of the mountains far away was sometimes so perfectly comprehensible to Natalie that she forced tears into her eyes, or lay on the grass, unable, after a point, to absorb it—she was, of course, adequately hidden from the windows of the house—or to turn it into more than her own capacity for containing it; she was not able to leave the fields and mountains alone where she found them, but required herself to take them in and use them, a carrier of something simultaneously real and unreal to set up against the defiantly real-and-unreal batterings of her family. There was a point in Natalie, only dimly realized by herself, and probably entirely a function of her age, where obedience ended and control began; after this point was reached and passed, Natalie became a solitary functioning individual, capable of ascertaining her own believable possibilities.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The girl next to her had hair that grew in an ugly line across her forehead, and when Natalie risked saying, after rehearsing it for some minutes, "Do you know any of these people?" the girl said, "No," briefly, eyed Natalie for a minute, and then looked away. She is not looking for me, Natalie thought, and the girl on her other side was not looking for Natalie either; as Natalie turned to her, to repeat her question, she rose quickly and went to join the group by the red-haired girl. Will they all notice that I am sitting almost alone? Natalie wondered. Did the red-haired girl thank her fate every morning and night, when she looked at herself in her mirror, with a comb in her hand? Did the girl near Natalie bewail secretly the ugly line of her hair, and persuade herself that she was more aware of it than anyone else? Was someone regarding Natalie, identifying her by some extraordinary characteristic which Natalie did not know or had forgotten or had convinced herself that no one saw? Was it not possible that the girl over there, in the blue dress, had put the dress on that morning wondering if it would do for her first day at college? Because it would not, and had she spent the day concerned with it, or had she forgotten it immediately she put it on? Had the mother of the one in green told her not to forget her pills? Was the one with glasses afraid of waking in the night, alone? Which of them had come to college hoping secretly to meet a thin nervous girl named Natalie? Did she expect Natalie to recognize her first? And, worst of all, what terrible change were they all expecting so immediately, so fearfully? Was something going to happen?

Natalie had already discovered that it was not possible to think clearly in this bedlam, any more than it was possible to act clearly.

Or, perhaps, waking Natalie as the obvious, destined victim? War? Pestilence? Terror?

"Initiation," called a long voice down the hall. "All freshmen out ."

"No," said Natalie, and reached for the cord of her light. Was she a freshman? So designated by those who did not know her name? Or had she been awakened by mistake—or _was_ this meant for her? Natalie alone, then? (Her untrusted mind playing her tricks? A dream, so that she should stand in a moment, shivering and miserable, alone in the hall while doors opened up and down the length of the building and curious, mocking faces peered out, saying, "What _is_ she doing?" and answering, "She dreamed, she dreamed she was a freshman and it was something called initiation, she keeps saying something about a murder, she keeps asking what her name is, she doesn't seem to know where she is .

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"I will _not_ ," said Natalie, who, like everyone else there, was more afraid of being found not to know dirty jokes than of being found to have a rich supply. "Don't you know _enough_ jokes?"

"Bad sport," someone called, and then others took it up. "Bad sport, rotten sport, not fair."

What a silly routine, Natalie thought, not realizing, sitting there alone on the stool in the center of the ring of girls, how she was jeopardizing her own future in college, her own future for four years and perhaps for the rest of her life; how even worse than the actual being a bad sport was the state of mind which led her into defiance of this norm, this ring of placid, masked girls, with their calm futures ahead and their regular pasts proven beyond a doubt; how one person, stepping however aside from their meaningless, echoing standards, set perhaps by a violent movement before their recollection, and handed down to them by other placid creatures, might lose a seat among them by questions, by rebellion, by anything except a cheerful smile and the resolution to hurt other people.

faithfulness_original_text.text: On either side of Natalie as she walked toward her own room were doors: perhaps behind one door a girl was studying, behind another a girl was crying, behind a third a girl was turning uneasily in her sleep. Behind a certain definite door downstairs Anne and Vicki sat, laughing and speaking in loud voices whatever they chose to say; behind other doors girls lifted their heads at Natalie's footsteps, turned, wondered, and went back to their work. I wish I were the only person in all the world, Natalie thought, with a poignant longing, thinking then that perhaps she was, after all. She reached her own door, and wondered again—Is this possible, my _own_ door? Can it be that after so short a time I can recognize one door among many, and call it "my own"? Or is it only from here, in the hall, that it looks so extraordinary—after all, I can only go _out_ one door from my room; it's coming in that is so confusing.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Hope Mother's not disappointed. Give her my love.

Natalie.

Perhaps—and this was her most persistent thought, the thought that stayed with her and came suddenly to trouble her at odd moments, and to comfort her—suppose, actually, she were _not_ Natalie Waite, college girl, daughter to Arnold Waite, a creature of deep lovely destiny; suppose she were someone else?

Suppose, for instance, that all of this, from the day she could first remember (running through the grass, calling, "Daddy? Daddy?"), suppose it had all been no more than a split second of time, as in a dream, perhaps under an anesthetic; suppose that after this split second when her wandering mind fancied she was someone named Natalie Waite, that then she should wake up, bemused at first, and speaking thickly, and not really quite sure of her surroundings and the nurse bending over her and the voices saying, "There now, it wasn't so bad, was it?" and suppose, waking, she should turn out to be someone else, someone real as Natalie was not? An old woman, perhaps, with a year or so to live, or a child having its tonsils removed, or a woman with twelve children having a charity operation, or a man.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
And, waking, looking around the white room and at the clean nurse, she could say, "I had the funniest dream all this time; I dreamed I was Waitalie Nat"—the dream already fading, and not complete—and the nurse could easily say, " _Everyone_ has dreams under ether," moving capably forward with a thermometer.

Or even suppose, imagine, could it be true? that she was confined, locked away, pounding wildly against the bars on the window, attacking the keepers, biting at the doctors, screaming down the corridors that she was someone named Watalie Naite . suppose, during the time she thought she was eating in the dining room and going unwillingly to classes and sitting in her room reading . suppose these things were not real? Could it be that some sudden lucid horrible moment (a new treatment, perhaps? An inevitable return to actuality?) should show her brutally that the dining room and the professors were not at all there, but existed far away in her mind, provoked into life only by her mania? "I'm not prepared today," she could be saying to her music professor, and the doctor, turning back her eyelid to look at her cornea, would murmur, "How long has she been in this particular stage?"

But then, perhaps she was not dreaming, not mad, but alive and sound—living in this caught second of life only in the musing mind of some salesgirl or waitress or prostitute or some drab creature to whom the life of a girl in college named Naitalie Wat seemed romantic; suppose somewhere a murderess slept lightly, dreaming for a minute that she was young again and had a life to live; suppose that some minute, any minute, she should suddenly turn, move her head, speak strangely, and find herself not at all real?

It was this that made her write her name crazily on everything, knowing and yet forgetting that her books and her clothes and her written sheets of paper would be gone with Natalie Waite, were only part of a larger dream; it was this which gave her the sudden sense, in conversation perhaps, that this particular portion of her dream might be condensed, only a fleeting shorthand scrap of words to be remembered later as a whole conversation; it was this which brought her abruptly to a perception that if she were dreaming her room and her words, she might well be dreaming her world, and so when she awoke she might say, amused, to the nurse, to the girl in the room next door, to the police, "Listen to what I dreamed; I dreamed there was a war; I dreamed there was a thing called television; I dreamed—listen to this—that there was something called an atom bomb. An _atom_ bomb— _I_ don't know; I tell you I _dreamed_ it."

Beyond this sense, however, of swift transient passage, was the worse, the frightful, conviction, of perhaps being in reality no more than Natalie Waite, college girl, daughter to Arnold, and unable to brush away the solidity of this world but forced to deal with it as actual and dreary.

She could hear, when the bus stopped, that more people were crowding and pushing in, with ill humor and complaint. Poor things, she thought—do they have to spend all this energy just to surround me? sentence_level_citation.sentence: Throughout the novel, Natalie's view of reality changes markedly, highlighting her internal conflict between belonging and alienation.

At first, she struggles with her sense of self, perceiving herself as just a "college girl" shaped by outside pressures instead of her authentic identity, while reflecting on her life and societal roles.

Beyond this sense, however, of swift transient passage, was the worse, the frightful, conviction, of perhaps being in reality no more than Natalie Waite, college girl, daughter to Arnold, and unable to brush away the solidity of this world but forced to deal with it as actual and dreary.

Behind the house, behind even the kitchen garden, Mr. Waite had graciously permitted trees to grow unmolested, and when Natalie was younger, before the garden and the view from the cliff had taken such a hold of her, she had delighted in playing pirate and cowboy and knight in armor among the trees. Now, however, for some reason only remotely connected with knights in armor, the tree on the grass belonged to her, and she ignored the trees below as dark and silent and unprovocative.

The sight of the mountains far away was sometimes so perfectly comprehensible to Natalie that she forced tears into her eyes, or lay on the grass, unable, after a point, to absorb it—she was, of course, adequately hidden from the windows of the house—or to turn it into more than her own capacity for containing it; she was not able to leave the fields and mountains alone where she found them, but required herself to take them in and use them, a carrier of something simultaneously real and unreal to set up against the defiantly real-and-unreal batterings of her family. There was a point in Natalie, only dimly realized by herself, and probably entirely a function of her age, where obedience ended and control began; after this point was reached and passed, Natalie became a solitary functioning individual, capable of ascertaining her own believable possibilities.

What a silly routine, Natalie thought, not realizing, sitting there alone on the stool in the center of the ring of girls, how she was jeopardizing her own future in college, her own future for four years and perhaps for the rest of her life; how even worse than the actual being a bad sport was the state of mind which led her into defiance of this norm, this ring of placid, masked girls, with their calm futures ahead and their regular pasts proven beyond a doubt; how one person, stepping however aside from their meaningless, echoing standards, set perhaps by a violent movement before their recollection, and handed down to them by other placid creatures, might lose a seat among them by questions, by rebellion, by anything except a cheerful smile and the resolution to hurt other people.

"I will _not_ ," said Natalie, who, like everyone else there, was more afraid of being found not to know dirty jokes than of being found to have a rich supply. "Don't you know _enough_ jokes?"

"Bad sport," someone called, and then others took it up. "Bad sport, rotten sport, not fair."

On either side of Natalie as she walked toward her own room were doors: perhaps behind one door a girl was studying, behind another a girl was crying, behind a third a girl was turning uneasily in her sleep. Behind a certain definite door downstairs Anne and Vicki sat, laughing and speaking in loud voices whatever they chose to say; behind other doors girls lifted their heads at Natalie's footsteps, turned, wondered, and went back to their work. I wish I were the only person in all the world, Natalie thought, with a poignant longing, thinking then that perhaps she was, after all. She reached her own door, and wondered again—Is this possible, my _own_ door? Can it be that after so short a time I can recognize one door among many, and call it "my own"? Or is it only from here, in the hall, that it looks so extraordinary—after all, I can only go _out_ one door from my room; it's coming in that is so confusing.

953f58e56ced4dc0b01aaf363657e39f_fiction.question: In what ways do Martha's emotions toward Jimmy Manning evolve and shift?
953f58e56ced4dc0b01aaf363657e39f_fiction.answer: Martha's emotions for Jimmy Manning start with curiosity and pleasure in his presence, suggesting a budding attraction.However, her emotions change drastically when she learns that he has violated her trust by recording their kiss as part of a wager.This betrayal prompts her to reconsider her feelings for Jimmy while also imparting significant lessons about the intricacies of friendship and romantic love.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
She held him in her stare for a long time, so long he started to blush and fidget.

"Well, the bet was nothing, really," he said. "Just a joke. I bet Vince and my brothers that I could get you to kiss me on video before they came back from sailing.

"Sure," I said.

4c54536b5fe34d52986f262028bb88d7_fiction.question: In what ways does Doro exercise control over his people?
4c54536b5fe34d52986f262028bb88d7_fiction.answer: Doro exerts control over his followers by utilizing a mix of selective breeding and his distinctive supernatural power to inhabit and dominate various bodies.This managed breeding, refined over almost four millennia, leads to reduced genetic variation among his followers, promoting their dependence on him for survival and wellbeing.His ability to transfer consciousness enables him to exert influence and retain dominance over individuals, further strengthening his control.

faithfulness_original_text.text: They always involved children, always had to do with his breeding programs. For all but the first few centuries of his four-thousand-year life, he had been struggling to build a race around himself. He existed apparently as a result of a mutation millennia past. His people existed as a result of less wildly divergent mutations and as a result of nearly four thousand years of controlled breeding.
anchor: His people existed as a result of less wildly divergent mutations and as a result of nearly four thousand years of controlled breeding.

23871ef0e660466e8552d3c85382bbb3_fiction.question: What ethical dilemmas do the characters in the book encounter?
23871ef0e660466e8552d3c85382bbb3_fiction.answer: In the book, characters confront various ethical dilemmas, mainly focusing on the choice to undergo an abortion, as one character's parents, although initially appalled, make arrangements for the procedure under medical supervision.Furthermore, there is an intricate debate concerning the obligation of doctors to act in medical emergencies, which prompts inquiries about the potential legal consequences they might encounter.Ultimately, medical students face the challenge of placing patient care above their own academic achievements, which adds another dimension to the ethical dilemmas they encounter.These dilemmas emphasize the complex balance between individual beliefs, professional duties, and the ethical consequences of their decisions.

One had paid fifty bucks to a shady character in a dingy two-room apartment on the fifth floor of a tenement near Red Hook. The second girl had told her parents who, though horrified, had arranged for an abortion under sterile medical conditions.

fa4bc7f0e7724fa6b3301bcf5b9eed62_fiction.question: In what ways does the theme of revenge appear in Margo's behavior and the broader storyline of "Once Upon a River"?
fa4bc7f0e7724fa6b3301bcf5b9eed62_fiction.answer: In "Once Upon a River," the theme of revenge is intricately intertwined with Margo's journey as she contends with the consequences of her traumatic experiences, especially the assaults by her uncle Cal and Paul.Margo's contradictory feelings expose her difficulty in balancing the desire for revenge with the awareness of its possible repercussions.She considers handling the situation herself, thinking about injuring Cal instead of killing him, reflecting her profound inner struggle with the concepts of violence and justice.Even though she understood that revenge could be harmful, Margo's desire for Paul to feel remorse for his actions shows her yearning for justice and the healing she links to holding her aggressors accountable for their wrongdoing.In the end, the story portrays the intricacies of vengeance, showing how Margo's longing for payback serves as both a motivating factor in her journey and a cause of inner conflict, as she balances the delicate distinction between justice and self-sabotage.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Her daddy had threatened to kill her uncle, and that was likely what he was coming to do. Margo thought Crane could not survive being locked up for the crime he was about to commit. She also knew Crane wouldn't shoot a man who was hurt or lying on the ground. She wondered if she should take Cal down herself before Crane got there, injure Cal rather than kill him.
anchor: She wondered if she should take Cal down herself before Crane got there, injure Cal rather than kill him.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Junior had stopped picking on her after that. The time she had revenged Billy with the dead skunk he'd put in her boat, she had to endure Joanna's tomato juice bath—a consequence she had not considered, as her daddy pointed out—and she stank for a week anyway. But it had been worth it to rub that skunk in Billy's face and hair. Her cousins had teased her, enjoyed her shrieks when they could elicit them, but they were also scared of her because she always evened the score.
anchor: Her cousins had teased her, enjoyed her shrieks when they could elicit them, but they were also scared of her because she always evened the score.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I know you understand that. I know you'll get even with your cousin someday."

She nodded. She knew better than to want revenge, but she couldn't let go of her desire for it.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
She practiced to get the length right, flipping the rifle from her left side quickly up to aim and press the trigger with her right index finger. When she finished, she thought her homemade hasty sling felt as fine and solid as the one on her daddy's old Remington, the rifle with which she'd performed that miracle of winning the 4-H competition.

Margo made herself a supper of cheese, crackers, summer sausage, and wild blackberries and was grateful not to be eating fish.

Though she knew revenge was as likely to hurt as it was to heal, she hoped she would make Paul regret what he had done.

46a3f6257e694d7391e15224d1adee7e_fiction.question: What is the main theme of "Eastern Standard Tribe"?
46a3f6257e694d7391e15224d1adee7e_fiction.answer: The main theme of "Eastern Standard Tribe" focuses on the interplay between personal loyalty and individual happiness, especially as shaped by technology and virtual communities.The story examines how these relationships are influenced by the allegiances people have to their social groups or "tribes," frequently resulting in clashes with wider human connections and personal satisfaction.The narrative underscores the intricacies of contemporary relationships and the importance of these digital connections in influencing an individual's identity and emotional well-being.

faithfulness_original_text.text: "So you get the Tribes. People all over the world who are really secret agents for some other time zone, some other way of looking at the world, some other zeitgeist. Unlike other tribes, you can change allegiance by doing nothing more than resetting your alarm clock. Like any tribe, they are primarily loyal to each other, and anyone outside of the tribe is only mostly human.
anchor: Like any tribe, they are primarily loyal to each other, and anyone outside of the tribe is only mostly human.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: The main theme of "Eastern Standard Tribe" focuses on the interplay between personal loyalty and individual happiness, especially as shaped by technology and virtual communities.

The story examines how these relationships are influenced by the allegiances people have to their social groups or "tribes," frequently resulting in clashes with wider human connections and personal satisfaction.
The narrative underscores the intricacies of contemporary relationships and the importance of these digital connections in influencing an individual's identity and emotional well-being.

e1dacef061204c6799139a61e4c33fe6_fiction.question: What is the main emotion that the narrator feels upon finding the letter from Clyde Jones?
e1dacef061204c6799139a61e4c33fe6_fiction.answer: The narrator feels a deep sorrow, described as a weighty sensation that envelops them following the discovery of the letter from Clyde Jones.This sadness arises from heartbreak and is exacerbated by reminders of the broken relationship, highlighting the emotional burden of loss and memory.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Here She Is.

It's an ache. A heavy sadness. The kind that is brought on by heartbreak and then perpetuated by everything that reminds you of the way it's broken.
anchor: The kind that is brought on by heartbreak and then perpetuated by everything that reminds you of the way it's broken.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"We'll think of something," Charlotte says, sitting next to me.

We sit in silence for a while, listening to the neighbors. They talk and laugh, and soon some music starts. I'm trying to push away the heavy feeling that's descending now, that has been so often lately, but I'm having trouble.
anchor: I'm trying to push away the heavy feeling that's descending now, that has been so often lately, but I'm having trouble.

c0e95f74290e48e0bec99ce0b540f3e7_fiction.question: What is the primary conflict in Stephenie Meyer's book "Twilight"?
c0e95f74290e48e0bec99ce0b540f3e7_fiction.answer: The primary conflict in "Twilight" by Stephenie Meyer revolves around Bella Swan's connection with Edward Cullen, a vampire, which presents considerable risks because of external dangers.Bella confronts threats from Victoria, a vindictive vampire determined to retaliate for her mate's death by coming after Bella, in addition to the Volturi, the vampire royal family that aims to eradicate humans aware of their existence.The conflict between Bella's human existence and the dangerous realm of vampires forms the central struggle in the story.

faithfulness_original_text.text:

Afternoons were the hardest part of my day. Ever since my former best friend (and werewolf), Jacob Black, had informed on me about the motorcycle I'd been riding on the sly — a betrayal he had devised in order to get me grounded so that I couldn't spend time with my boyfriend (and vampire), Edward Cullen — Edward had been allowed to see me only from seven till nine-thirty p.

50df70ca1b4e4c2c822312a0b346f50c_fiction.question: What is the profession of the main character, and which languages does he instruct?
50df70ca1b4e4c2c822312a0b346f50c_fiction.answer: The protagonist, Josef Vadassy, is a language instructor.He instructs in German, English, and Italian, and sometimes in Hungarian as well.

faithfulness_original_text.text:

I produced the card from my wallet and handed it over. He drew a sheet of paper towards him and began making notes.

"Age?"

"Thirty-two."

"You are, I see, a teacher of languages.

faithfulness_original_text.text: My mother had died during the war and I had no other relations or friends. I was advised not to attempt to return to Yugoslavia. Conditions in Hungary were terrible. "German, English, and Italian, occasionally Hungarian also.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Soviet Russia would have no more use for a convicted spy than would England. Even the Chinese wanted your passport. There would be nowhere I could go, nowhere. d67ef5f2b999433e8857195c1419d4bd_fiction.question: What is the main setting of "Every Heart a Doorway"?
d67ef5f2b999433e8857195c1419d4bd_fiction.answer: The main location of "Every Heart a Doorway" is Eleanor West's Home for Wayward Children, a boarding school created for children who have come back from magical and fantastical worlds.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Her small wheeled suitcase was bright pink, covered with cartoon daisies. She had not, in all likelihood, purchased it herself.

Raising her hand to shield her eyes, the girl looked toward the manor, pausing when she saw the sign that hung from the porch eaves. ELEANOR WEST'S HOME FOR WAYWARD CHILDREN it read, in large letters.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: The main location of "Every Heart a Doorway" is Eleanor West's Home for Wayward Children, a boarding school created for children who have come back from magical and fantastical worlds.

cf1eca4a459e4a97bfd665333f308bec_fiction.question: What is Ruth's vision for her future, and in what ways does she try to engage Sylvia, Greta, and George in it?
cf1eca4a459e4a97bfd665333f308bec_fiction.answer: Ruth has chosen to take her life and is looking for the participation of Sylvia, Greta, and George in this last act.She communicates her intentions by explicitly outlining her plans and requesting their support and companionship, indicating a deep connection between them as she confronts this pivotal moment.Specifically, Ruth relies on Sylvia to assist with the implementation of her plan, while Greta is essential in offering physical support throughout the process.In contrast, George stands as a sentinel, emphasizing the urgency and closeness of their shared experience.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"Don't look so worried, you don't need to be nervous with us."

"I do, actually. You'll see. Because what I want is—all right, here goes: I plan to end my life fairly soon. The favour I'm asking is for you to be with me come the time. And much more than that, even, I need you to help me."

What? Ruth wants what?

"I'm intending to die, and I'd like your assistance.
anchor: Because what I want is—all right, here goes: I plan to end my life fairly soon.

"

What? Ruth wants what?

"I'm intending to die, and I'd like your assistance.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Or it's not.

Is it strange that the air among them now contains sizzles of anger?

"Just think about it, okay? It's truly not so outrageous, believe me."

Really? In what way is helping Ruth kill herself likely to become less outrageous, and how long does she think that will take? Who, honest to God, does she suppose them to be?

That's not even to mention, what on earth are they going to talk about from now on? The weather, Greta's knitting, their children, the latest flood, fire, war? Everything, everything lies in a distressing new light, and this is Ruth's fault. There were the months before she said, more or less, "I'm planning to end my life fairly soon, and I'd like you all to be with me, and beyond that to help me," and now there will be after.
anchor: There were the months before she said, more or less, "I'm planning to end my life fairly soon, and I'd like you all to be with me, and beyond that to help me," and now there will be after.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
There is, then, this debt to them all, and a payment Greta can make that no one else swiftly and mercifully can.

If she can. If she is called to.

It is Sylvia who is to remove the carefully folded dry-cleaner bag from under the belt of her robe, Sylvia who is to hold it up between her knobby, outstretched hands, ready, but it is Greta who is to help Ruth raise up her head so the plastic can slip smoothly over it, Greta who is to reach for the roll of duct tape with its end already folded back so there's no fumbling, Greta who is to quickly, as smoothly as she can, wind and wrap the tape around and around, pinning plastic to throat.

As George keeps watch in the doorway, ready or unready to warn of intrusion, it's to be Greta and Sylvia hovering right over Ruth, witness to the whuffing in and out of the plastic, the O of last breaths, the brief but bound-to-be-frantic struggle.

e594b0bcd805442da07cc054aff3bf95_fiction.question: In what way does Nolan's understanding of his link to Amara's healing influence his behavior?
e594b0bcd805442da07cc054aff3bf95_fiction.answer: Nolan's understanding that he could have a considerable impact on Amara's healing leads him to take a more active role in her life.Realizing that his bond with her is essential, he starts to take steps to safeguard her and looks for ways to assist her in fleeing from Jorn.This realization not only boosts his feeling of accountability but also drives him to confront the moral implications of his impact on her situation, prompting him to rethink how he utilizes their bond.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
And—

_Whoever's causing this will catch on and try again._

They were talking about Nolan. Had to be. He'd thought he was dependent on Amara's blackouts to take control, but did Ruudde's words mean it was the other way around? What if the blackouts were his doing—Nolan piggybacking on whatever connection Amara's faulty magic had established and _using_ it instead of letting it use _him_? She'd suspected her panic had activated the blackouts, but Nolan had panicked just as much as she had.

be2f79c0173b4e0cbd5a4d9b21774281_fiction.question: In what ways does Mishka Bartok's character embody the themes of obsession and personal identity?
be2f79c0173b4e0cbd5a4d9b21774281_fiction.answer: Mishka Bartok's character illustrates the themes of obsession and personal identity through his deep relationship with music, which ultimately becomes his only priority.The close environment of the sound booth, referred to as a "small dark space," represents his withdrawal from the external world and emphasizes how his passion has evolved into an obsession.This obsession not only defines his identity but also alienates him, mirroring a wider conflict with the intricacies of self-exploration and the difficulties of establishing authentic relationships outside of his musical endeavors.

faithfulness_original_text.text: He supposed he must have been happy in the nine floating months before his birth. He supposed contentment must also have bathed his mother in that time when she could rest a hand on her belly and she and her son could converse in code, tapping out musical notations in the blood. He remembered also the womb-like contentment of the first six years of his life. He knew this was why the small dark space of the sound booth and the wick's nimbus and the music and the sound of his heartbeat all added up to an addiction.

faithfulness_original_text.text: I shoved my hands into my pockets and in the long slant of the late afternoon sun I walked down Main Street which should have been familiar to me but didn't feel so. And here was Sandstone Street and a block north was the parking lot of Rosie's where Jake and I had smashed the lights of Morris Engdahl's Deuce Coupe.

f9e3d2f317ca4aba97378e1a151b3c1a_fiction.answer: Vadassy's scheme to ensnare the spy ultimately collapses when he is confined in the writing-room by the person who seizes his camera, which he had positioned as bait.This spy successfully obtains the camera without being recognized, leaving Vadassy powerless and lacking any evidence to back his claims, placing him in a precarious situation.

faithfulness_original_text.text:

ac28b8d9f5974c83b2b4a88a7fd9ef03_fiction.question: In what ways do Samantha's passions for swimming and writing poetry assist her in managing her OCD?
ac28b8d9f5974c83b2b4a88a7fd9ef03_fiction.answer: Samantha's combined passions for swimming and writing poetry act as therapeutic outlets that assist her in managing her OCD.The rhythmic aspect of swimming enables her to concentrate her mind, whereas the process of writing poetry provides a productive outlet for her feelings and ideas.She frequently composes her poems while swimming, which aids her in organizing her thoughts and diverts her from obsessive patterns.Following her swims, she transcribes these poems onto paper, though she observes that they seldom retain the original clarity they possessed in her thoughts.This method offers her a creative outlet that can help alleviate the anxiety linked to her OCD.Furthermore, the organized schedule of swimming paired with the personal expression discovered in poetry enhances her overall feeling of control and wellness.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
From the main compartment, I grab my towel, and when I do, I spot my blue notebook. It's such a nice night, so I stuffed it in here at the last minute, thinking I might sit on the lawn and write for a while after my workout.

I've never actually _written_ at the pool before. My poems come to me as I'm swimming, and I put them on paper when I get home, but they never sound quite as good as they did in my head.

1a5ebc69b6234158ad1db6fac3812eda_fiction.question: What is the importance of the tire iron in the story?
1a5ebc69b6234158ad1db6fac3812eda_fiction.answer: The tire iron in the narrative represents the main character's quest for security and an element of excitement.Although it is uncommon to look for protection in a seemingly secure place like New Bremen, the request emphasizes the character's apprehension about walking home at night and reinforces a wish for empowerment in an unpredictable situation.Moreover, the tire iron symbolizes a defiant attitude, indicating a readiness to challenge conventions despite fear, highlighting the character's intricate connection with bravery and fragility.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"Frank, you and Jake are going to have to walk home. Do you have a problem with that?"

"No, sir. We'll be fine. But could we have the tire iron from the trunk? For protection?"

New Bremen wasn't at all the kind of town where you'd need a tire iron for protection but I nodded toward Jake, whose face had gone a little white at the prospect of walking home in all that dark, and my father understood.

e11695e2116c477d820790dac6f75a73_fiction.question: In what way does the idea of "Tribes" operate within the narrative?
e11695e2116c477d820790dac6f75a73_fiction.answer: In the story, "Tribes" function as online communities that surpass geographic boundaries, enabling members to participate in cooperative activities grounded in common time zones.Participants frequently adjust their sleeping patterns to coincide with the prime activity hours of their Tribe, establishing a distinctive rhythm of engagement that promotes both connection and productivity, even with the difficulties of residing in various locations.This framework emphasizes the combination of online social interaction and professional involvement, as members assist one another in different pursuits around the clock.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
There was a Pacific "look" that was indefinably off. Hard to say what it was, just that when he went out to a bar or got stuck on a crowded train, the girls just didn't seem all that attractive to him. Objectively, he could recognize their prettiness, but it didn't stir him the way the girls cruising the Chelsea Antiques Market or lounging around Harvard Square could.

He'd always felt at a slight angle to reality in California, something that was reinforced by his continuous efforts in the Tribe, from chatting and gaming until the sun rose, dragging his caffeine-deficient ass around to his clients in a kind of fog before going home, catching a nap and hopping back online at 3 or 4 when the high-octane NYC early risers were practicing work-avoidance and clattering around with their comms.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Nelson of James Madison University for discovering the uncollected stories in the Richard Yates Collection at Boston University in 1996.
