ALL MISS PRICE had been told about the new boy was that he'd spent most of his life in some kind of orphanage, and that the gray-haired "aunt and uncle" with whom he now lived were really foster parents, paid by the Welfare Department of the city of New York. A less dedicated or less imaginative teacher might have pressed for more details, but Miss Price was content with the rough outline. It was enough, in fact, to fill her with a sense of mission that shone from her eyes, as plain as love, from the first morning he joined the fourth grade.
anchor: It was enough, in fact, to fill her with a sense of mission that shone from her eyes, as plain as love, from the first morning he joined the fourth grade.

faithfulness_original_text.text: The idea of the reports—a fifteen-minute period every Monday in which the children were encouraged to relate their experiences over the weekend—was Miss Price's own, and she took a pardonable pride in it. The principal had commended her on it at a recent staff meeting, pointing out that it made a splendid bridge between the worlds of school and home, and that it was a fine way for children to learn poise and assurance. It called for intelligent supervision—the shy children had to be drawn out and the show-offs curbed—but in general, as Miss Price had assured the principal, it was fun for everyone. She particularly hoped it would be fun today, to help put Vincent Sabella at ease, and that was why she chose Nancy Parker to start off; there was nobody like Nancy for holding an audience.
anchor: She particularly hoped it would be fun today, to help put Vincent Sabella at ease, and that was why she chose Nancy Parker to start off; there was nobody like Nancy for holding an audience.

faithfulness_original_text.text: She managed to control the same impulse at recess the next day, and every other day that week, though every day it grew more difficult. But one thing she could not control was a tendency to let her anxiety show in class. All Vincent Sabella's errors in schoolwork were publicly excused, even those having nothing to do with his newness, and all his accomplishments were singled out for special mention. Her campaign to build him up was painfully obvious, and never more so than when she tried to make it subtle; once, for instance, in explaining an arithmetic problem, she said, "Now, suppose Warren Berg and Vincent Sabella went to the store with fifteen cents each, and candy bars cost ten cents.

2ca7614844814077b31766d6781600bc_fiction.question: In what way does Vadassy first try to prove his innocence after being charged with espionage?
2ca7614844814077b31766d6781600bc_fiction.answer: Vadassy first tries to exonerate himself after being charged with espionage by strategically positioning his camera in a spot where all hotel guests can notice it.He intends to watch from a concealed location, aiming to identify the person who shows interest in the camera and might take it, thereby uncovering the individual engaged in the espionage operation.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Beghin had pointed out that when and if that person discovered the loss of his or her photographs, he or she would be anxious to recover them. Now, for all that person knew, they were still in the camera. Therefore, if that person saw an opportunity of re-exchanging the cameras, he or she would certainly take it.

My idea was to plant the Contax I had in some conspicuous place at a time when all the guests would have an opportunity of seeing it, retreat somewhere whence I could see the camera without being seen and wait for results.

950c51fff0924b4f97da8453101a88b5_fiction.question: In what ways does Ted Lambros's experience as a commuter student influence his integration into Harvard life?
950c51fff0924b4f97da8453101a88b5_fiction.answer: Ted Lambros's identity as a commuter student greatly influences his assimilation into Harvard life, resulting in a marked feeling of isolation.He occupies his time at Harvard as a "part and yet apart," participating in academics but going home every night, which limits his capacity to connect with other students and completely engage in campus culture.His severely limited social life, restricted to weekends, highlights this sense of detachment, as he realizes he lacks a substantial social network and feels alienated from his peers.As a result, even though he is part of the academic community, he is still burdened by the discouraging belief that "the people at Harvard still hate me," which deepens his sense of isolation.

# FIVE LIVES, FIVE LOVE STORIES—THE DRAMATIC PORTRAIT OF A GENERATION

DANNY ROSSI, the musical prodigy, risks all for Harvard, even a break with his domineering father. Yet his real problems are too much fame too soon—and too many women.

TED LAMBROS spends his four years as a commuter, an outsider.

All sensible people are selfish.

He was a commuter. A member of that small and near-invisible minority whose finances were not sufficient to allow them the luxury of living with their classmates on campus. Thus, they were Harvard men only by day—a part and yet apart—forced to return at night by bus or subway to the real world.

Ted Lambros was one of those unhappy few. For, being a commuter, he had not applied to any house and hence was completely unaffected by the news conveyed to all those living in the Yard.

03b52d5ef4d5450da947cdd3e9f6d279_fiction.question: What was the importance of the radio play concept in the introduction of "Everything's Eventual"?
03b52d5ef4d5450da947cdd3e9f6d279_fiction.answer: The concept of the radio play mentioned in the introduction of "Everything's Eventual" was important as it illustrated a creative approach to assist Stephen King's radio stations in becoming profitable.By utilizing his writing abilities to create a Halloween-themed audio play, King sought to earn money through syndication, converting his artistic project into a source of income for his stations.This method provided a solution to the issues with advertising revenue while also enabling the use of our in-house production resources and local actors, fostering community involvement and striving for financial stability.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"I'm in downtown Bangor, where roughly a thousand people are jammed into Pickering Square, watching as a large, silvery disc-like object descends toward the ground . wait a minute, if I raise the mike, perhaps you can hear it."

And, just like that, we'd be off to the races. I could use our very own in-house production facilities to create the audio effects, local community-theater actors to do the roles, and the best part? The very best part of all? We could record the result and syndicate it to stations all over the country! The resulting income, I figured (and my accountant agreed), would be "radio station income" instead of "creative writing income." It was a way to get around the advertising revenue shortfall, and at the end of the year, the radio stations might actually be in the black!

The idea for the radio play was exciting, and the prospect of helping my stations into a profit position with my skills as a writer for hire was also exciting.

3e43f6ddf38d4a0ba7abfc460af699dd_fiction.question: Who is Vincent Sabella, and what is his history?
3e43f6ddf38d4a0ba7abfc460af699dd_fiction.answer: Vincent Sabella is a new pupil in Miss Price's fourth-grade class, marked by a difficult background.He has lived the majority of his life in an orphanage, and at present, he is staying with foster parents who receive payment from the New York City Welfare Department for their support.

85da0e3b0d8f4de9bb21c9561b68a198_fiction.question: What enigmatic occurrence takes place at the school that initiates the plot?
85da0e3b0d8f4de9bb21c9561b68a198_fiction.answer: The story begins with the murder of Sumi, a student at the school.This startling incident generates a stressful environment for the students, leading to the necessity of establishing a routine to help them stay grounded and avoid additional anxiety following her death.The event triggers investigations that uncover deeper truths among the students, as suggested by allusions to previous disturbing incidents involving them.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Nancy looked back at Sumi's pictures on the bulletin board, so quiet, so still. Then she turned off the light and closed the door.

SURVIVORS, FOR A TIME

MORNING CLASSES HAD BEEN canceled; they resumed after lunch. Maybe it was rushing things, but there was nothing else to do with an entire school's worth of anxious, uneasy students: routine would keep them from wandering off and frightening themselves to death in the aftermath of Sumi's murder.
anchor: Maybe it was rushing things, but there was nothing else to do with an entire school's worth of anxious, uneasy students: routine would keep them from wandering off and frightening themselves to death in the aftermath of Sumi's murder.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Jill gasped, leaping to her feet. "Loriel!" she shrieked, the sound of her voice bringing all other conversation in the dining hall grinding to a halt. "How could you?"

"It was an accident," said Loriel. "Just like your sister there 'accidentally' took apart Angela's guinea pig, and 'accidentally' murdered Sumi.

81af352d015545c3b5206d1e892b0096_fiction.question: What ethical challenges does Mary encounter as she takes control over other telepaths?
81af352d015545c3b5206d1e892b0096_fiction.answer: Mary struggles with considerable ethical challenges as she takes charge of other telepaths.A significant worry is the exploitation of their emotions, which she acknowledges could be used against them, leading to a power disparity that endangers their independence and emotional security.Moreover, Mary is highly cognizant of the fundamental risks associated with wielding such power, especially the dangers of controlling skilled telepaths "on mental leashes," indicating an ethical dilemma regarding the possible harm her actions may cause to others.Ultimately, her effort to tap into the mental energy of the crowd without inflicting actual harm reflects her recognition of the duty that accompanies her powers, emphasizing the conflict between meeting her own desires and protecting the welfare of those under her influence.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I wanted them the way they were now, at ease, comfortable with me.

I realized that there was something really proprietary about my feelings toward them. As though I was supposed to have charge over them and they were supposed to accept me. But I also realized that I had no idea how dangerous it might be for me to hold a group of experienced active telepaths on mental leashes.
anchor: But I also realized that I had no idea how dangerous it might be for me to hold a group of experienced active telepaths on mental leashes.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
All she retained was enough to make her nervous sometimes. Nervous and vulnerable to Eli. But not now.

Now she drew all she dared from the small crowd, forcing herself to stop before she was satisfied, to avoid doing them any real harm.
anchor: Now she drew all she dared from the small crowd, forcing herself to stop before she was satisfied, to avoid doing them any real harm.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
And the way they had been acting for the past few days, I didn't see how I could get away with taking just one. Neither of them was going to sit by and watch the other killed.

That bothered me. I realized that their feelings for each other could be used against them—that, for a while at least, I could control one by threatening the other.

e3e851645ab84a738f96deebb184bd41_fiction.question: What is the main theme of "Eleven Kinds of Loneliness"?
e3e851645ab84a738f96deebb184bd41_fiction.answer: The main focus of "Eleven Kinds of Loneliness" is the examination of various forms of loneliness and isolation encountered by individuals.The story explores the subtle despair of overlooked existences, demonstrating that even in a lively setting like a town teeming with soldiers, people frequently contend with deep emotions of isolation and disconnection.The narratives expose the intricate and multifaceted essence of loneliness in different circumstances and connections.

faithfulness_original_text.text: I'm sure none of us expected him to spend his free time with us—the thought would never have occurred to us, in fact—but the smallest glimpse into his personal life would have helped. If he had ever reminisced with us about his home, for instance, or related the conversations of his PX friends, or told us of a bar he liked in town, I think we would all have been touchingly grateful, but he never did. And what made it worse was that, unlike him, we had no real life outside the day's routine. The town was a small, dusty maze of clapboard and neon, crawling with soldiers, and to most of us it yielded only loneliness, however we may have swaggered down its avenues.
anchor: The town was a small, dusty maze of clapboard and neon, crawling with soldiers, and to most of us it yielded only loneliness, however we may have swaggered down its avenues.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The Collected Stories reminds us how dangerous a writer Richard Yates is. No one should know this much about us."

And what made it worse was that, unlike him, we had no real life outside the day's routine. The town was a small, dusty maze of clapboard and neon, crawling with soldiers, and to most of us it yielded only loneliness, however we may have swaggered down its avenues.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: The narratives expose the intricate and multifaceted essence of loneliness in different circumstances and connections.

78e487f2bd884315b05702a8867e56c8_fiction.question: In what ways does the setting of "Karen Makes Out" impact the story and its characters?
78e487f2bd884315b05702a8867e56c8_fiction.answer: The location of "Karen Makes Out," set in Hollywood, has a substantial impact on the narrative and its characters.The glamorous yet misleading environment of Hollywood sets a complicated stage for Karen Sisco, a U.S.marshal, as she juggles her personal connections with her challenging career.The surreal nature of the environment, filled with hopeful starlets and opportunistic characters, intensifies the obstacles Karen encounters, emphasizing themes of ambition and ethical uncertainty in a realm where looks can be deceptive.This setting not only influences Karen's character growth but also heightens the tension in the story, as the attraction of fame and achievement frequently conflicts with the truths of her profession.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
He needed a car for a new business he was getting into.

**Get Shorty** (1990)

Mob-connected loanshark Chili Palmer is sick of the Miami grind — plus his "friends" have a bad habit of dying there. So when he chases a deadbeat client out to Hollywood, Chili figures he might like to stay. This town with its dreammakers, glitter, hucksters, and liars — plus gorgeous, partially clad would-be starlets everywhere you look — seems ideal for an enterprising criminal with a taste for the cinematic.

7b7aa11b344c47afa43d10c279746172_fiction.question: In what way does the river's setting function as a metaphor in "Once Upon a River"?
7b7aa11b344c47afa43d10c279746172_fiction.answer: In "Once Upon a River," the river acts as a strong symbol for the journey of life and the intricacies of individual identity.It represents the unpredictable and frequently severe realities that people, especially girl children like Margo, have to deal with.The river's cold and detached character mirrors not only the difficulties Margo encounters in her search for belonging but also the emotional gap from her mother, who left her, emphasizing the battle for connection and self-discovery in the face of hardship.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Margo Crane has the deadeye poise of her heroine Annie Oakley and the tender heart of the child she is. When she sets out on her journey on that Michigan river we are both delighted and terrified. We want her to make her way; we want her to be safe and happy. But the world is not kind to girl children on their own, and the river is as cold and dispassionate as some of those Margo meets—including the mother who abandoned her so long ago.
anchor: But the world is not kind to girl children on their own, and the river is as cold and dispassionate as some of those Margo meets—including the mother who abandoned her so long ago.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: In "Once Upon a River," the river acts as a strong symbol for the journey of life and the intricacies of individual identity.
It represents the unpredictable and frequently severe realities that people, especially girl children like Margo, have to deal with.

The river's cold and detached character mirrors not only the difficulties Margo encounters in her search for belonging but also the emotional gap from her mother, who left her, emphasizing the battle for connection and self-discovery in the face of hardship.

f368668d50e34e21bf2934f029bdf6ef_fiction.answer: Lilly shares a profound bond and emotional connection with her father, James Patrick Dunne.He conveys his affection in a touching way, frequently welcoming Lilly with open arms and a kiss, symbolizing the closeness and connection they have.This relationship profoundly impacts Lilly, influencing her feelings of pride and respect for him throughout her life, as emphasized by her fond memories of their interactions.

faithfulness_original_text.text: The commissioner, dressed as my father said 'in a London suit of the finest sort', had come over from said London and was formally bestowing on my father, my own father, the signs and formulas of his new condition. I know now he was to lead the B division of the Dublin Metropolitan Police, and had risen now as high as he could ever expect, after thirty years in the police. No Wicklow sunrise over Keadeen Mountain, where our cousins and aunts and uncles still lived, could have matched the brightness, the shavenness and utmost delight in his face. It was the same look I saw every evening I came home from school, and I ran into his arms, and he kissed me, and said, 'If I didn't have your kiss I might never come home', but magnified a thousand times.

27ef338e99d043b6a56308dc736e6167_fiction.question: What are the protagonist's feelings toward the dark?
27ef338e99d043b6a56308dc736e6167_fiction.answer: The protagonist holds a profound admiration for the darkness, considering it a companion in their clandestine and defiant ideas.They convey a feeling of thrill and excitement linked to nighttime, which they characterize as a moment when the world is still, enabling introspection and a sense of sinfulness tied to their desires.The darkness also evokes emotions of love and belonging, as shown by their thoughts while sitting outside their father's church, where they delight in the night's embrace.

Jake almost always stuttered in public but around me he only stuttered when he was mad or scared.

"No," I replied, "but I can p-p-p-pound the crap out of you any time I want."

He found his sneakers and began to put them on.

Night was the dark of the soul and being up in an hour when the rest of the world was dead with sleep gave me a sinful thrill.

I sat on the steps of my father's church thinking how much I loved the dark. The taste of what it offered sweet on the tongue of my imagination. The delicious burn of trespass on my conscience.

2f313ee0ac9b4ed7be8e0b16956e69cb_fiction.answer: The primary villain in the novel "City Primeval" is Clement Mansell, known as the "Oklahoma Wildman.".Homicide Detective Raymond Cruz is resolute in making sure that Mansell does not escape justice once more following earlier incidents.

she told the white cop that, too, and the white cop agreed, nodding, and then he was saying, "Oh, by the way .

**City Primeval: High Noon in Detroit** (1980)

Clement Mansell knows how easy it is to get away with murder. The seriously crazed killer is already back on the Detroit streets — thanks to some nifty courtroom moves by his crafty looker of a lawyer — and he's feeling invincible enough to execute a crooked Motown judge on a whim. Homicide Detective Raymond Cruz thinks the "Oklahoma Wildman" crossed the line long before this latest outrage, and he's determined to see that the hayseed psycho does not slip through the legal system's loopholes a second time.

a227fa2e506345078adc1c2d0b749496_fiction.question: In what way does the relationship between Greta Bauer and George Hammond develop throughout the book?
a227fa2e506345078adc1c2d0b749496_fiction.answer: The relationship between Greta Bauer and George Hammond undergoes considerable change throughout the story.At first, it begins as a clandestine relationship within their careers, marked by a blend of yearning and restraint.Nonetheless, as the narrative unfolds and they arrive at the Idyll Inn, their connection evolves into a nurturing friendship.In this context, they offer each other companionship and support, emphasizing their dependence on one another as they face the challenges of their lives together.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
At the third door they rap lightly and, no need for invitation, go through. Here they have to exert themselves; there's some effort and clumsiness involved in adding this companion to the last leg of their journey.

They are, all three, grateful for each other's presence. They have long since discovered the comforts of companionship, but now the knowledge is sharp and specific and shared: whatever would they do without each other tonight?

Probably they would be sleeping, safe and unanguished and innocent; it will soon be too late to say.

a47607b2f6454c6fbe391891b0fed43f_fiction.question: What is the importance of Natalie's relationships with her classmates at college?
a47607b2f6454c6fbe391891b0fed43f_fiction.answer: Natalie's engagements with her classmates at college are important as they emphasize the conflict between individuality and conformity.While she interacts with girls who represent a more traditional and serene lifestyle, she struggles with her own artistic values and the societal pressures that come with them.This struggle highlights her concerns about putting her future at risk, as she understands that straying from the norm could jeopardize her acceptance in this peer group.Her acts of defiance against their accepted norms uncover a significant conflict between preserving her true self and the longing for social approval, indicating that her connections profoundly shape her self-perception and her role in society.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"I will _not_ ," said Natalie, who, like everyone else there, was more afraid of being found not to know dirty jokes than of being found to have a rich supply. "Don't you know _enough_ jokes?"

"Bad sport," someone called, and then others took it up. "Bad sport, rotten sport, not fair."

What a silly routine, Natalie thought, not realizing, sitting there alone on the stool in the center of the ring of girls, how she was jeopardizing her own future in college, her own future for four years and perhaps for the rest of her life; how even worse than the actual being a bad sport was the state of mind which led her into defiance of this norm, this ring of placid, masked girls, with their calm futures ahead and their regular pasts proven beyond a doubt; how one person, stepping however aside from their meaningless, echoing standards, set perhaps by a violent movement before their recollection, and handed down to them by other placid creatures, might lose a seat among them by questions, by rebellion, by anything except a cheerful smile and the resolution to hurt other people.

What a silly routine, Natalie thought, not realizing, sitting there alone on the stool in the center of the ring of girls, how she was jeopardizing her own future in college, her own future for four years and perhaps for the rest of her life; how even worse than the actual being a bad sport was the state of mind which led her into defiance of this norm, this ring of placid, masked girls, with their calm futures ahead and their regular pasts proven beyond a doubt; how one person, stepping however aside from their meaningless, echoing standards, set perhaps by a violent movement before their recollection, and handed down to them by other placid creatures, might lose a seat among them by questions, by rebellion, by anything except a cheerful smile and the resolution to hurt other people.

4023436201fb4942a0e90cd9b44b0037_fiction.question: What does the title "Olive's Ocean" signify?
4023436201fb4942a0e90cd9b44b0037_fiction.answer: The title "Olive's Ocean" carries important significance as it alludes to a touching entry from Olive Barstow's journal, in which she reveals her wish to see the Atlantic or Pacific Ocean.This desire takes on symbolic significance for Martha as she contemplates Olive's aspirations during her visit to her grandmother's cottage by the Atlantic Ocean, emphasizing themes of yearning and a bond with nature and memory.

I also hope that one day I can go to a real ocean such as the Atlantic or Pacific.

7038aa767a9d437384ef6a8b55e0a351_fiction.question: What function does Stonehenge serve in the story of "Sarum"?
7038aa767a9d437384ef6a8b55e0a351_fiction.answer: In the story of "Sarum," Stonehenge is depicted as an essential location for astronomical observations and religious ceremonies.It is portrayed as a place where priests performed sacrifices to the sun god and the moon goddess, highlighting its spiritual significance to the nearby communities.Additionally, the architectural elements of Stonehenge, including its outer circle of wooden markers and standing stones, emphasize its significance in regulating societal activities across the expansive territory ruled by chief Krona, illustrating the advanced astronomical knowledge possessed by its creators.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"But we are different," its priests proudly declared. From the entrance on the north east side, a broad avenue between earth walls cut a straight, ceremonial path for six hundred yards across the landscape. At the point where it joined the sanctum, a pair of huge grey stones formed the gateway through which only the priests and their sacrificial victims ever passed. Within, there were two small mounds used for astronomical observations, an outer circle of fifty-six wooden markers which the present High Priest had carefully restored, and a double inner circle – as yet only half completed – of standing stones. These were the sacred bluestones.

The henge was already eight hundred years old and it was a place of mystic significance. Not only was it the site at which the priests made the ritual sacrifices to the sun god and the moon goddess: it had important astronomical properties central to the ordering of all activities in the huge territory of Sarum and its great chief Krona.

e2b31bf833374ebf9ffd9d06febc7b77_fiction.question: What technological innovations brought by the farmers greatly influence the lives of the hunters in "Sarum"?
e2b31bf833374ebf9ffd9d06febc7b77_fiction.answer: In "Sarum," the innovations brought about by farmers—especially the creation of farming tools, the building of sturdy wooden structures, and improvements in pottery—significantly affect the lives of hunters.These innovations enhance living standards and bolster food security, facilitating a shift from a nomadic way of life to a more stable and prosperous existence for both groups.The practices of the farmers facilitate improved resource management and a more stable community, which in turn benefits hunters by ensuring a more dependable source of food and shelter.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Elsewhere in the Middle East, other peoples were developing new and sophisticated crafts: in Egypt they made linen; in Mesopotamia, clever jewellers were combining copper brought down from the mountains with glass, in beautiful and intricate patterns to make the ornamental work called faience. On the coast of Saudi Arabia, divers searched the oyster beds for pearls which they exported, and in the Levant, merchants were putting out to sea in small ships rigged with square leather sails, carrying cargoes of copper, ivory and brightly painted pottery.

Further north, in Europe, there were no towns. But in that huge belt of land stretching from the Danube to the Baltic, farmers were planting crops, raising livestock, and burning the stubble to enrich the soil; and they were building huge wooden barns and houses, sometimes a hundred feet long.

1a8ed1e9303f4f05b0147aa0e076e3ad_fiction.question: What struggle does the main character, Samantha McAllister, face throughout the book?
1a8ed1e9303f4f05b0147aa0e076e3ad_fiction.answer: In the book, Samantha McAllister struggles with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), which is defined by intrusive and uncontrollable thoughts.She faces intense thought spirals that are hard to manage and frequently result in physical and mental fatigue as she attempts to cope with them.Furthermore, her challenges are intensified by the stigma surrounding her condition, leading her to hesitate in discussing her experiences with friends.This struggle with her mental health shows up as feelings of loneliness and fear, as she faces her irrational thoughts and attempts to gain a sense of empowerment by recognizing her difficulties.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I throw my arms around Mom's shoulders, hugging her hard, hoping this is the last time we go through this but knowing it isn't. The anxiety attacks are like earthquakes. I'm always relieved when the ground stops shaking, but I know there will be another one eventually, and again, I'll never see it coming.

"What am I going to tell them?"

My friends can't know about my OCD or the debilitating, uncontrollable thoughts, because my friends are normal.

####

I became interested in writing a story about a teen with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) when a close family friend was diagnosed four years ago, at age twelve. I sympathized with and related to her battle with insomnia, her struggles to interpret her friends' words and actions, and her challenges to control a stream of negative, often terrifying thoughts she simply couldn't turn off.
anchor: I sympathized with and related to her battle with insomnia, her struggles to interpret her friends' words and actions, and her challenges to control a stream of negative, often terrifying thoughts she simply couldn't turn off.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I wanted to learn more about this disorder and to understand what it was like to live inside her mind. She was eager to share her experience, and I was honored when she agreed to work with me on this novel.

Over the last two years, I've done extensive research on OCD and what some refer to as Purely Obsessional or "Pure-O" OCD, where the emphasis is more on internal thoughts and images than external compulsions. I've learned that many professionals consider the term a bit of a misnomer—compulsions are still part of the disorder, they're simply easier to hide—but many people with OCD use "Pure-O" to differentiate an obsession with their _thoughts_ from the better-known external behaviors, like ritualized hand washing or lock checking.
anchor: I've learned that many professionals consider the term a bit of a misnomer—compulsions are still part of the disorder, they're simply easier to hide—but many people with OCD use "Pure-O" to differentiate an obsession with their _thoughts_ from the better-known external behaviors, like ritualized hand washing or lock checking.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I've consulted closely with four mental-health professionals to be sure this work of fiction portrays an accurate account of OCD, while also demonstrating the value of a strong patient-therapist relationship. It has been enlightening, inspiring, and heartbreaking.

During my research, I became especially interested in exposure therapy, a subset of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). I found it empowering, and wove it into the story when Sam's mother hands her a pair of scissors to prove that she won't _act_ on her invasive, fearful thoughts.
anchor: I found it empowering, and wove it into the story when Sam's mother hands her a pair of scissors to prove that she won't _act_ on her invasive, fearful thoughts.

485483f0b1174e2bada3849e5b3f9e44_fiction.question: What is the importance of the jar of seawater that Martha intends to give to Olive's mother?
485483f0b1174e2bada3849e5b3f9e44_fiction.answer: The jar of seawater that Martha intends to present to Olive's mother carries profound meaning as it represents Martha's attempt to pay tribute to Olive's memory.It symbolizes a concrete link to Olive’s dreams, particularly her desire to encounter the ocean, which she wrote about in her journal.In giving the jar as a gift, Martha recognizes the disparity between the seemingly trivial item and the expansive ocean it symbolizes, emphasizing both her individual bond with Olive and the broader aspirations they held together.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Her parents were decent about privacy, so she didn't have to bury her things in the back corners of her closet, just place them in her bottom right desk drawer where they were hidden from plain sight but accessible.

The jar of water for Olive's mother had survived the trip beautifully. When Martha had unwrapped it, she half expected it to be cracked and empty, the T-shirt that protected it wet. She found it strange that something so insignificant—the jar—could contain a piece, however tiny, of something so grand—the ocean.

c13cbc55b09f4a06b5f6e915a06ac6c0_fiction.question: What is the importance of the long barrows in the story of "Sarum"?
c13cbc55b09f4a06b5f6e915a06ac6c0_fiction.answer: In the story of "Sarum," the long barrows possess considerable cultural and historical significance.They symbolize the early Neolithic burial customs in Britain and demonstrate a profound respect for the dead, based on the belief that the departed observed the living.These edifices function not just as burial places for individuals but also as collective memorials for families or groups, demonstrating a lasting legacy of remembrance and tradition spanning thousands of years.Moreover, the gathering of these burial mounds on Salisbury Plain highlights their lasting significance and presence in the landscape, representing the link between ancient traditions and modern identity.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
At such times, it seemed to him that the old man's spirit spoke to him quietly, giving him good advice; and he would return to the valley, strengthened.

This was not the only manifestation of Krona's abiding presence: for often, when the summer thunder rolled over the ridges the people of Sarum would look at each other and say:

"That's Krona, rumbling in his house."

Years afterwards, when he in turn had chosen one of Krona's sons to succeed him, Gwilloc marked out for himself and his family a similar though more modest tomb half a mile away, so that his spirit also should remain properly housed near the place where the rivers met.

And so began at Sarum the first building of the great earth tombs known as long barrows that are the distinguishing mark of Neolithic Britain and which have lasted for over five thousand years. From this time on, through generation after generation, other tombs would arise out of the ground in the Sarum area as farming communities cleared and settled the land. Sometimes the barrows became the tombs of families or groups, but others continued to be built as memorials to some individual great man. Their use spread further afield over Britain. As millennia passed they took on many forms – some round, some saucer-shaped. But it is on the high rolling downland of Salisbury Plain that to this day one of the greatest concentrations of all can be seen, where several hundred barrows overgrown with grass – brooding presences from the island's ancient days – dot mile after mile of the landscape.

But it is on the high rolling downland of Salisbury Plain that to this day one of the greatest concentrations of all can be seen, where several hundred barrows overgrown with grass – brooding presences from the island's ancient days – dot mile after mile of the landscape.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
It was a night full of stars. The dew on the bare ridges, which swept majestically away on every side, caused them to shimmer in the moonlight.

On every ridge of the sacred region, chalk barrows jutted out of the turf – some long, others round – pale forms which glimmered, even from miles away, like ghostly ships, frozen upon a vast unmoving sea. For the dead watched over the living at Sarum, and were honoured accordingly.

840098f418c84f9e8dd17191a195f8c1_fiction.question: In what way did the notebook act as a metaphor for Alfie Zimmer's life in "All That You Love Will Be Carried Away"?
840098f418c84f9e8dd17191a195f8c1_fiction.answer: In "All That You Love Will Be Carried Away," the notebook represents Alfie Zimmer's life by mirroring his fixation on graffiti, which acts as a more profound metaphor for his identity and challenges.It embodies his secretive character and dual life; although he superficially portrays himself as an ordinary reporter marketing routine items, he is, in reality, involved in a fervent and clandestine realm of rebellion associated with the Communist insurgent, Pedro Núñez.The notebook symbolizes the intricacy of his personality, embodying the struggle between his professional outward appearance and his concealed interests, thereby highlighting his internal conflict and the diverse dimensions of his life.

faithfulness_original_text.text: The way thinking a stove burner might still be on sometimes nagged him when he was home, nagged until he finally got up and checked and found it cold. Only this was worse. Because he loved the stuff in the notebook. Amassing graffiti—thinking about graffiti—had been his real work these last years, not selling price-code readers or frozen dinners that were really not much more than Swansons or Freezer Queens in fancy microwavable dishes.

4ff47dbe43344b0e9171de5881acfe2f_fiction.question: What is the importance of the recurring theme of music in the novel, and in what ways does it affect the characters' behaviors and feelings?
4ff47dbe43344b0e9171de5881acfe2f_fiction.answer: The theme of music in the novel is essential in influencing the characters' feelings and behaviors, serving as a channel for their internal experiences and their relationships with each other.Characters such as Mishka are profoundly connected to music, existing within "melodies trapped in her head," indicating that sound and sensation are essential to their identities and how they perceive the world.This sensory link reflects their emotional conditions and affects their actions, frequently resulting in deep contemplation or instances of vulnerability.Additionally, music encapsulates the theme of loss, exemplified by the singer whose rendition expresses sorrow, flowing "from body to body like a low electrical charge," reflecting a collective experience of grief that reverberates among the characters.The feeling of descending freely into a "well of melody without end" further emphasizes how music enables characters to transcend their realities, indicating a desire for comfort and comprehension during difficult moments.Therefore, music not only enriches the emotional terrain of the story but also strengthens the characters' quest for connection amid their challenges.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The man who had stepped back from the outbound train leaned against a pillar with his eyes closed, rapt. Leela saw a woman surreptitiously wiping her sleeve across her eyes.

The violin itself was weeping music. Sometimes it wept alone; sometimes the tenor voice sorrowed along with it in a tongue not quite known but intuitively understood. The singer was singing of loss, that much was certain, and the sorrow was passing from body to body like a low electrical charge.

1811a5ab10d64cca90a54645c1f75600_fiction.question: What does the nickname "Doctor Jack-o'-Lantern" assigned to Vincent Sabella signify?
1811a5ab10d64cca90a54645c1f75600_fiction.answer: The moniker "Doctor Jack-o'-Lantern" assigned to Vincent Sabella emphasizes the theme of misinterpretation and mockery within social interactions.It stems from his inaccurate citation of "Doctor Jekyll and Mr.Hyde" during a class presentation, demonstrating how a minor error can result in ridicule from classmates, as shown by the eruption of laughter and the chorus of corrections from his peers after the mispronunciation.This event highlights the wider difficulties of managing social interactions, especially for individuals who are already susceptible to criticism.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"Saw, Vincent," Miss Price corrected gently.

"That's what I mean," he said; "I sore that pitcha. Doctor Jack-o'-Lantern and Mr."

There was a burst of wild, delighted laughter and a chorus of correction: "Doctor Jekyll!"

He was unable to speak over the noise.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"Think I care if yiz believe me?"

But he was walking alone. Warren Berg and Bill Stringer were drifting away across the street, walking backwards in order to look back on him with furious contempt. "Just like the lies you told about the policeman shooting your father," Bill Stringer called.

"Even movies he lies about," Warren Berg put in; and suddenly doubling up with artificial laughter he cupped both hands to his mouth and yelled, "Hey, Doctor Jack-o'-Lantern!"

It wasn't a very good nickname, but it had an authentic ring to it —the kind of a name that might spread around, catch on quickly, and stick.

9ec54e2fe730421782728e685d429993_fiction.answer: The book explores the themes of forgiveness and self-acceptance through the protagonist's journey, where she comes to forgive herself for her past mistakes and embraces her OCD as a crucial part of her identity.This transformative journey is essential for her attainment of inner peace and happiness, as emphasized by her heartfelt expression of self-forgiveness.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"Go for it," she says quietly.

I'm not sure how long I sit there wiping my eyes and blowing my nose, but I know even if we go overtime on our session today, there's no way she'll let me leave this chair until I say it. And mean it.

"I forgive myself," I finally say, my voice cracking on each word.

a6c2afac5eff4f7e9d0865cb8f7d55a8_fiction.question: What does the title "Every Heart a Doorway" signify?
a6c2afac5eff4f7e9d0865cb8f7d55a8_fiction.answer: The title "Every Heart a Doorway" represents the concept that within every person exists a personal route to distinctive and fantastical worlds, embodying their innermost wishes and internal journeys.This concept is captured in the idea that what one genuinely desires can be reached through these symbolic doors, opening up to realms that align with their deepest longings.For example, the characters pursue doors that satisfy their unarticulated needs and desires, implying that their hearts serve not only as containers of emotion but also as portals for exploration and identity.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
The moors didn't seem to care about stillness, only obedience and blood. Neither of those things were strong suits of hers. All around her, other students exchanged equally uncomfortable glances, making their own connections and finding them just as unpleasant as she did.

"Sumi had Nonsense in her heart, and so a door opened that would take her to a world where she could wear it proudly, not hide it away.
anchor: "Sumi had Nonsense in her heart, and so a door opened that would take her to a world where she could wear it proudly, not hide it away.

I hope the same, for each of you. I want to make excuses to your parents when you disappear, to tell them that runaways will always run again if they have half the chance. I want to see the back of you more than I want almost anything in this world."

What she wanted most didn't need to be spoken, for they shared her hunger, her brutal, unforgiving desire: what she wanted most was a door, and the things that waited on its other side.

8226acb66885405db072a1eac4631a50_fiction.question: What is the importance of Innocent House in the narrative?
8226acb66885405db072a1eac4631a50_fiction.answer: Innocent House is of great significance as the main office of Peverell Press, a well-known and reputable publishing company.Built in 1830 for Sir Francis Peverell, this structure showcases magnificent architectural design with its Venetian-inspired elements and vibrant marble exterior, representing the rich history and legacy of the publishing industry it embodies.Its impressive facade along the Thames not only designates it as a significant architectural landmark but also highlights the cultural heritage associated with its publishing roots.

faithfulness_original_text.text: She could hear its rhythmic slap against the stone. She walked slowly towards it in a trance of wonder as if she had never seen it before. It shimmered before her, a wide expanse of heaving sun-speckled water which, as she watched, was flicked by the strengthening breeze into a million small waves like a restless inland sea, and then, as the breeze dropped, mysteriously subsided into shining smoothness. And, turning, she saw for the first time the towering wonder of Innocent House, four storeys of coloured marble and golden stone which, as the light changed, seemed subtly to alter colour, brightening, then shading to a deeper gold.
anchor: And, turning, she saw for the first time the towering wonder of Innocent House, four storeys of coloured marble and golden stone which, as the light changed, seemed subtly to alter colour, brightening, then shading to a deeper gold.

Defendants taken into custody after their first hearing were removed to the Fleet prison; the more fortunate walked down the cobbled lane to freedom. He had started to tell his son something of the house's architectural history, but his voice had been overpowered by the tour-guide's booming commentary, loud enough to be heard by every boat on the river.

"And here, coming up on our left, ladies and gentlemen, is one of the most interesting buildings on the Thames: Innocent House, built in 1830 for Sir Francis Peverell, a noted publisher of the day.

47e5f6beebfd47d4a525902ea096155b_fiction.question: In what ways did the setting of the deathroom in "In the Deathroom" enhance the overall atmosphere of the story?
47e5f6beebfd47d4a525902ea096155b_fiction.answer: The environment of the deathroom in "In the Deathroom" is essential in creating a terrifying and stifling ambiance.The gray industrial tile and stained white stone walls, featuring darker splotches that imply blood, create an atmosphere of dread and aggression, emphasizing the harshness of the interrogation happening within that area.The stark and severe lighting, characterized as being contained in wire cages, further heightens the bleak atmosphere, emphasizing the looming danger of death and the mental anguish experienced by the protagonist【0】.This striking portrayal plunges the reader into a scenario filled with tension and fear, which is crucial to the story's effectiveness.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
## In the Deathroom

It was a deathroom. Fletcher knew it for what it was as soon as the door opened. The floor was gray industrial tile. The walls were discolored white stone, marked here and there with darker patches that might have been blood—certainly blood had been spilled in this room.
anchor: The walls were discolored white stone, marked here and there with darker patches that might have been blood—certainly blood had been spilled in this room.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: The environment of the deathroom in "In the Deathroom" is essential in creating a terrifying and stifling ambiance.

The gray industrial tile and stained white stone walls, featuring darker splotches that imply blood, create an atmosphere of dread and aggression, emphasizing the harshness of the interrogation happening within that area.

The stark and severe lighting, characterized as being contained in wire cages, further heightens the bleak atmosphere, emphasizing the looming danger of death and the mental anguish experienced by the protagonist【0】.
This striking portrayal plunges the reader into a scenario filled with tension and fear, which is crucial to the story's effectiveness.

ea6dde62ed524d05a04032be903ade07_fiction.question: In what ways does the book examine the idea of leadership and succession in the Sarum community?
ea6dde62ed524d05a04032be903ade07_fiction.answer: The book explores leadership and succession in the Sarum community by analyzing the practices and challenges encountered by its leaders, particularly through characters such as Krona and Gwilloc.It demonstrates how each chief took on the name Krona to represent continuity in leadership, while the position of High Priest was frequently occupied by a relative, thereby strengthening dynastic rule.This framework illustrates the challenges of upholding peace and allocating resources while guaranteeing consistent leadership over generations.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
For this was the heart of Sarum and the residence of the great chief Krona.

Since time out of mind, the family of the chief had ruled at Sarum. Claiming direct descent from the legendary Krona the Warrior whose long barrow on the high ground was still venerated, a list of no less than eighty generations of the family had been ceremoniously recited by the priests when the last chief's reign had been inaugurated. To emphasise the continuity of their rule, each chief took the same name – Krona – on his succession, and the office of High Priest was usually also occupied by some other member of the family.
anchor: To emphasise the continuity of their rule, each chief took the same name – Krona – on his succession, and the office of High Priest was usually also occupied by some other member of the family.

Since time out of mind, the family of the chief had ruled at Sarum. Claiming direct descent from the legendary Krona the Warrior whose long barrow on the high ground was still venerated, a list of no less than eighty generations of the family had been ceremoniously recited by the priests when the last chief's reign had been inaugurated. To emphasise the continuity of their rule, each chief took the same name – Krona – on his succession, and the office of High Priest was usually also occupied by some other member of the family.

d36dd008bd344967b1191e14b22cdfa1_fiction.question: In what ways does the book address the personal sacrifices that medical students make?
d36dd008bd344967b1191e14b22cdfa1_fiction.answer: The book highlights the considerable personal sacrifices that medical students endure, stressing their compromises in aspects like personal relationships, sleep, and leisure activities in order to focus on their rigorous studies.It examines the emotional and physical stress stemming from this demanding educational path and investigates its impact on students' mental health, ultimately illustrating the significant challenges they encounter throughout their training.

103003218e7344bf83b72d1e93d504b9_fiction.question: What is the main theme of "Every Heart a Doorway"?
103003218e7344bf83b72d1e93d504b9_fiction.answer: The main theme of "Every Heart a Doorway" focuses on the challenge of balancing the extraordinary experiences of otherworldly adventures with the ordinary realities of daily life.Characters struggle with the difficulty of reconciling their past experiences as they encounter the disregard of their memories and adventures by others, resulting in sensations of loneliness and a desire for a reality that seemed more genuine than their present life.This conflict emphasizes the emotional distress that surfaces when an individual faces the conclusion of a life-changing journey and the urge to grasp the fragments of that remarkable experience.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
com/piracy.
FOR THE WICKED
PART I

THE GOLDEN AFTERNOONS
THERE WAS A LITTLE GIRL

THE GIRLS WERE NEVER present for the entrance interviews. Only their parents, their guardians, their confused siblings, who wanted so much to help them but didn't know how. It would have been too hard on the prospective students to sit there and listen as the people they loved most in all the world—all this world, at least—dismissed their memories as delusions, their experiences as fantasy, their lives as some intractable illness.
anchor: It would have been too hard on the prospective students to sit there and listen as the people they loved most in all the world—all this world, at least—dismissed their memories as delusions, their experiences as fantasy, their lives as some intractable illness.

faithfulness_original_text.text: "She can't be blamed for what it made of her, any more than you can be blamed for the way you seem to stop breathing when no one's looking at you. She's going to need a lot of work before she's ready to face the world outside again, and she has to want to do it. That's what determines which school is better for you: the wanting. You want to go back, and so you hold on to the habits you learned while you were traveling, because it's better than admitting the journey's over.

5b77a70a2e2048e5bb36094d6fe23df3_fiction.question: In what ways does the death of Mary's husband, Mike, affect her during the course of the book?
5b77a70a2e2048e5bb36094d6fe23df3_fiction.answer: Mary's emotional journey in the book is profoundly influenced by the passing of her husband, Mike.Her sleepless nights are plagued by haunting images of the accident following his tragic death in a hit-and-run.The loss affects her mental health as she struggles with intense grief, but it also heightens her fears for her own safety and well-being, leading to worries from those around her.Furthermore, Mike's passing raises doubts in Mary about potential links between his tragic accident and other occurrences in her life, prompting her to contemplate her connections and the evolving situations surrounding her.In summary, Mike's death acts as a crucial catalyst for Mary's emotional challenges and the tension in the narrative.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
I feel sick and guilty, and most of all, in the dark and twisted pit of my stomach, I feel a powerful fear. I don't want to lose Brent like I lost Mike.

I close my eyes to the picture forming in my head, the one of the car slamming into Brent's body. It's like a nightmare, a waking nightmare, and one that I had on so many sleepless nights after Mike's death, as I pictured the car slamming into him on his bike.

5b7db3faaaf846d99375799440ec1554_fiction.question: In what ways does Martha's relationship with her grandmother, Godbee, develop over the course of the story?
5b7db3faaaf846d99375799440ec1554_fiction.answer: Martha's bond with her grandmother, Godbee, develops considerably over the course of the story as they grow closer.At first characterized by warmth, their connection deepens as they reveal personal stories and secrets to one another.Godbee is instrumental in motivating Martha to share her thoughts and chase her dream of becoming a writer, creating a nurturing atmosphere that enables Martha to delve into her feelings and creativity.This path of shared understanding and assistance emphasizes the transformative quality of their relationship.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
By her thin, but strong, grasshopper arms, her smell.

Godbee said, "Hug me, child," and "I do love you."

Martha could feel Godbee's breath on her ear, feel her cool, silky skin on her neck, feel a strand of her unpinned hair at the corner of her mouth.

Martha thought she'd break Godbee if she hugged her back as hard as she wanted to, but she was filled with such love and longing and happiness and sorrow (not bravery, definitely not bravery) that she grabbed her grandmother's shoulders and squeezed with all her might.

Godbee is instrumental in motivating Martha to share her thoughts and chase her dream of becoming a writer, creating a nurturing atmosphere that enables Martha to delve into her feelings and creativity.
This path of shared understanding and assistance emphasizes the transformative quality of their relationship.

18dd3e080af24dd0a5fe385e027ddcde_fiction.question: In what ways does the relationship between Mary and Karl develop over the course of the story?
18dd3e080af24dd0a5fe385e027ddcde_fiction.answer: Throughout the narrative, the connection between Mary and Karl evolves from early animosity and suspicion to a reluctant acceptance and shared reliance.At first, they do not agree, but as the story unfolds, Karl turns into a crucial supporter for Mary, helping her to manage and control the group of telepaths.This change highlights the themes of teamwork and the significance of building partnerships in difficult situations.

dae6c88824a94ceb9dfe53a52cc02bbb_fiction.question: In what ways does Grace's relationship with Ralph develop in "The Best of Everything"?
dae6c88824a94ceb9dfe53a52cc02bbb_fiction.answer: In "The Best of Everything," Grace's connection with Ralph evolves substantially from a casual acquaintance to a serious commitment.At first, Grace feels that the endearing term "darling" is foreign, mirroring her doubts about their relationship.However, as their connection strengthens and it becomes evident that they are meant to marry, she starts to welcome this new phase of their relationship.This change is characterized by surprising actions from Ralph that charm her and indicate a growing fondness she may not have initially foreseen.In the end, Grace's journey underscores the intricacies of romantic relationships and the slow embrace of love, despite early uncertainties.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
"

"Well listen, I gotta go over to Eddie's house and pick up that bag he's gonna loan me, so I might as well do that, go on home and eat, and then come over to your place around eight-thirty, nine o'clock. Okay?"

"All right," she said. "I'll see you then, darling." She had been calling him "darling" for only a short time—since it had become irrevocably clear that she was, after all, going to marry him—and the word still had an alien sound.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
And all the time Ralph kept calling up, hanging around, waiting for her to make up her mind. Once she took him home to meet her parents in Pennsylvania (where she never would have dreamed of taking Martha), but it wasn't until Easter time that she finally gave in.

They had gone to a dance somewhere in Queens, one of the big American Legion dances that Ralph's crowd was always going to, and when the band played "Easter Parade" he held her very close, hardly moving, and sang to her in a faint, whispering tenor. It was the kind of thing she'd never have expected Ralph to do—a sweet, gentle thing—and it probably wasn't just then that she decided to marry him, but it always seemed so afterwards.

a74bc3bded7b4ee38f1e8407993d7014_fiction.question: In what ways does Jason Gilbert's understanding of his Jewish identity change over the course of the story?
a74bc3bded7b4ee38f1e8407993d7014_fiction.answer: Jason Gilbert's understanding of his Jewish identity experiences a notable change throughout the story.At first, he attempts to separate himself from his Jewish heritage, pursuing acceptance and achievement mainly through his athletic abilities and charisma.However, after facing rejection from Yale because of his Jewish identity, he is driven to confront and accept this part of himself, resulting in a more unified understanding of his identity as a person.This journey illustrates larger themes of identity and belonging, emphasizing the difficulties encountered by individuals who struggle with their heritage in their quest for acceptance.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
Yet his real problems are too much fame too soon—and too many women.

TED LAMBROS spends his four years as a commuter, an outsider. He is obsessed by his desire to climb to the top of the Harvard academic ladder, heedless of what it will cost him in personal terms.

JASON GILBERT, the Golden Boy—handsome, charismatic, a brilliant athlete—learns at Harvard that he cannot ignore his Jewish background.

e93bd9ca2cdc439182fe80c3aa42b53d_fiction.question: In what ways does the book examine the influence of technology on human behavior and relationships?
e93bd9ca2cdc439182fe80c3aa42b53d_fiction.answer: The book explores the significant influence of technology on human behavior and relationships by emphasizing how communication devices, like smartphones and the internet, promote the creation of virtual communities.It highlights that these tools can foster a stronger bond with online peers while concurrently distancing individuals from their physical environment and conventional relationships with family and friends.This duality highlights a change in allegiance and self-perception, complicating traditional social interactions as people move through both online and offline environments.

Mortals may be promiscuous with their handsets, but for a tribalist, one's relationship with one's comm is deeply personal.

faithfulness_original_text.text: They choose their peers based on similarity, not geography, and they keep themselves awake at the same time as them. But you need to make some nod to localness, too—gotta be at work with everyone else, gotta get to the bank when it's open, gotta buy your groceries. You end up hardly sleeping at all, you end up sneaking naps in the middle of the day, or after dinner, trying to reconcile biological imperatives with cultural ones. Needless to say, that alienates you even further from the folks at home, and drives you more and more into the arms of your online peers of choice.

a15746437a9b4beebc9e8fc464ee7ddc_fiction.question: In "The Man in the Black Suit," how does the narrator express his emotions regarding the man he encountered in the woods?
a15746437a9b4beebc9e8fc464ee7ddc_fiction.answer: In "The Man in the Black Suit," the narrator conveys a deep sense of fear and discomfort regarding the man he met in the woods, whom he views as the Devil.This experience evokes a permanent fear that endures over his lifetime, as he contemplates the incident with a blend of anxiety and intrigue.The narrator explains that his reflections on the past only heighten his fear, indicating that the significance of this meeting has profoundly affected his mind throughout the years, highlighting the eerie quality of the experience.

faithfulness_original_text.text: I turned and began walking as fast as I could, limping a little—I'd pulled muscles in both legs, and when I got out of bed the next morning I was so sore I could barely walk. I didn't notice those things then, though. I just kept looking over my shoulder, needing again and again to verify that the road behind me was still empty. It was, each time I looked, but those backward glances seemed to increase my fear rather than lessening it.
anchor: It was, each time I looked, but those backward glances seemed to increase my fear rather than lessening it.

faithfulness_original_text.text: My infirmities have crept up like waves which will soon take a child's abandoned sand castle, and my memories have also crept up, making me think of some old rhyme that went, in part, "Just leave them alone/And they'll come home/Wagging their tails behind them." I remember meals I ate, games I played, girls I kissed in the school cloakroom when we played Post Office, boys I chummed with, the first drink I ever took, the first cigarette I ever smoked (cornshuck behind Dicky Hammer's pig-shed, and I threw up). Yet of all the memories, the one of the man in the black suit is the strongest, and glows with its own spectral, haunted light. He was real, he was the Devil, and that day I was either his errand or his luck.
anchor: He was real, he was the Devil, and that day I was either his errand or his luck.

5b37ce2b9c264b33b89fcaf16d6e1361_fiction.question: In what ways does Margo's relationship with her mother, Luanne, influence her life in the novel?
5b37ce2b9c264b33b89fcaf16d6e1361_fiction.answer: Margo's bond with her mother, Luanne, profoundly influences her life, cultivating feelings of abandonment and propelling her search for identity.The emotional emptiness created by Luanne's absence drives Margo to undertake a difficult journey upstream, motivated by a need to comprehend her mother's choices and mend their broken relationship.This journey underscores not only her desire for connection but also the stark truths encountered by young girls alone, as reflected in the cold and unfeeling characteristics of both the world and the river she traverses.In the end, Margo's quest illustrates her battle for acceptance and the intricate nature of family ties that influence her life.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Margo didn't miss her father any less as the weather warmed, but by then her body had absorbed the habit of sadness, so that sadness flowed all through her and became a natural part of her movements. Missing her mother was different; her mother was an agitation and a puzzle. She tried to imagine situations her mother might be in that were so delicate that they couldn't meet, not even for a visit. Was her mother being held prisoner? Was she taking care of some man's children, a dozen of them, so that she couldn't take care of one more person? Luanne should have known that Margo didn't need much taking care of.
anchor: Was her mother being held prisoner? Was she taking care of some man's children, a dozen of them, so that she couldn't take care of one more person? Luanne should have known that Margo didn't need much taking care of.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Painted turtles and blue racers sunning themselves on fallen trees slid into the water at her approach. A great blue heron fished silently from its perch on a root, one bulging banded eye on her as she passed, wary but not alarmed so long as Margo was moving with the current. She was tempted to take up the oars and row toward the bird, but decided to leave it in peace. She felt the exhaustion of her journey of the last ten months, the whole foolish, failed journey upstream to find her mother.
anchor: She felt the exhaustion of her journey of the last ten months, the whole foolish, failed journey upstream to find her mother.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Margo Crane has the deadeye poise of her heroine Annie Oakley and the tender heart of the child she is. When she sets out on her journey on that Michigan river we are both delighted and terrified. We want her to make her way; we want her to be safe and happy. But the world is not kind to girl children on their own, and the river is as cold and dispassionate as some of those Margo meets—including the mother who abandoned her so long ago.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: Margo's bond with her mother, Luanne, profoundly influences her life, cultivating feelings of abandonment and propelling her search for identity.
The emotional emptiness created by Luanne's absence drives Margo to undertake a difficult journey upstream, motivated by a need to comprehend her mother's choices and mend their broken relationship.

This journey underscores not only her desire for connection but also the stark truths encountered by young girls alone, as reflected in the cold and unfeeling characteristics of both the world and the river she traverses.

anchor_text: She felt the exhaustion of her journey of the last ten months, the whole foolish, failed journey upstream to find her mother.

prefix_text: Painted turtles and blue racers sunning themselves on fallen trees slid into the water at her approach. A great blue heron fished silently from its perch on a root, one bulging banded eye on her as she passed, wary but not alarmed so long as Margo was moving with the current. She was tempted to take up the oars and row toward the bird, but decided to leave it in peace. She felt the exhaustion of her journey of the last ten months, the whole foolish, failed journey upstream to find her mother.

Margo Crane has the deadeye poise of her heroine Annie Oakley and the tender heart of the child she is. When she sets out on her journey on that Michigan river we are both delighted and terrified. We want her to make her way; we want her to be safe and happy. But the world is not kind to girl children on their own, and the river is as cold and dispassionate as some of those Margo meets—including the mother who abandoned her so long ago.

sentence_level_citation.sentence: In the end, Margo's quest illustrates her battle for acceptance and the intricate nature of family ties that influence her life.

anchor_text: Was her mother being held prisoner? Was she taking care of some man's children, a dozen of them, so that she couldn't take care of one more person? Luanne should have known that Margo didn't need much taking care of.
prefix_text: Margo didn't miss her father any less as the weather warmed, but by then her body had absorbed the habit of sadness, so that sadness flowed all through her and became a natural part of her movements. Missing her mother was different; her mother was an agitation and a puzzle. She tried to imagine situations her mother might be in that were so delicate that they couldn't meet, not even for a visit. 6d90b412f9784d6c81854b87a25cc6b8_fiction.question: What is the importance of the blackouts that Amara goes through?
6d90b412f9784d6c81854b87a25cc6b8_fiction.answer: The blackouts that Amara endures are important because they signify a loss of control over her body and mind, which gives Nolan the opportunity to possibly exploit the situation for his benefit.This connection alarms other characters, especially Jorn, who fears that Amara's blackouts might endanger their safety and make them vulnerable to dangers from their adversaries.The characteristics of these blackouts indicate a complicated interaction between Amara's magical powers and Nolan's impact, emphasizing the possibility of manipulation within disorder.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
And—

_Whoever's causing this will catch on and try again._

They were talking about Nolan. Had to be. He'd thought he was dependent on Amara's blackouts to take control, but did Ruudde's words mean it was the other way around? What if the blackouts were his doing—Nolan piggybacking on whatever connection Amara's faulty magic had established and _using_ it instead of letting it use _him_? She'd suspected her panic had activated the blackouts, but Nolan had panicked just as much as she had.

4795e3a18d0841deacb47bbfeaf3b464_fiction.question: What is the importance of the title "On Canaan's Side"?
4795e3a18d0841deacb47bbfeaf3b464_fiction.answer: The title "On Canaan's Side" holds profound meaning, representing a quest for safety and tranquility, evoking the biblical territory of Canaan.It illustrates Lilly's journey for comfort in the face of her personal losses and challenges.The allusions to Canaan suggest a quest for a promised land or a sense of belonging, especially when confronting challenges in America, as demonstrated by the moving statements regarding Dr.King's assassination happening "on Canaan's side itself.".Furthermore, the concept of Canaan conjures feelings of hope and opportunity, as it implies a lively potential despite previous struggles.In summary, the title encompasses the themes of yearning, dislocation, and the aspiration for a more promising future.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
But we were walking arm in arm, jubilant, exultant, and barely noticed, and anyway did not care.

He was suddenly full of plans. It was as if he had awakened to being in America, abruptly made manifest to him as a place of safety, maybe infinite safety. As if he had suddenly remembered he was young, and though banished from his own country, might have come to America anyway, in the natural way of an Irish person, and now it was all laid out before him, before us, like a glittering Canaan.
anchor: As if he had suddenly remembered he was young, and though banished from his own country, might have come to America anyway, in the natural way of an Irish person, and now it was all laid out before him, before us, like a glittering Canaan.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
He looked at it. Big tears started in his eyes. He looked at me again with a last look, and almost fell out into the street, clutching the photograph. Then he plunged away, to what he thought was his proper life, into the river of people, the confused torrent of people, into Canaan itself.
**_Fourteenth Day without Bill_**

About this time, Dr King was shot.

Ed came home on leave, and he was an absolutely unsmiling young man that time. The man on the TV said the tragedy was all the greater because Dr King had been killed in America, 'on Canaan's side itself'.

38120d5024f0438d9dab6a39d8daa7c8_fiction.question: In what way does Cilla's curse affect the storyline?
38120d5024f0438d9dab6a39d8daa7c8_fiction.answer: Cilla's curse greatly influences the story by creating a feeling of urgency and danger.Her delicate condition, where even a small scratch could be fatal, generates ongoing stress as Amara assumes the duty of safeguarding her.This situation not only raises the stakes of their interactions but also makes their movements more complex in the world, as they must deal with threats while making sure Cilla stays safe from danger, which can also put Amara in jeopardy.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
He would've killed Cilla, too, had one of the palace mages—Jorn—not smuggled her out in time.

When Ruudde and the other ministers had discovered Cilla's escape, they'd cursed her. And while that curse was active, she was too fragile to make her survival public. Anyone could kill her with a scratch.
anchor: Anyone could kill her with a scratch.

faithfulness_original_text.text: Amara's head snapped back. If he'd caught her reading the sign. But, no, he kept moving and indicated for them to follow. Amara guided Cilla through the center of the boardwalk, keeping a close eye on spaces to flee to and on people who risked bumping into Cilla.

80193c63d5e54656b3129602e3408d64_fiction.question: In what ways does Sergeant Reece's leadership style affect his platoon in "Jody Rolled the Bones"?
80193c63d5e54656b3129602e3408d64_fiction.answer: Sergeant Reece's approach to leadership in "Jody Rolled the Bones" greatly influences his platoon.His composed manner and firm commands initially incited resentment among the soldiers, evident when he pushed them into overt hostility during close-order drill.Nonetheless, Reece also exhibits traits that earn respect; he acknowledges soldiers by recalling their names and easing his reprimands, indicating recognition of their development.These conflicting signals establish a complicated relationship where, in spite of his harshness and emotional detachment, instances of camaraderie emerge, like when he gives a wink to the soldiers, indicating a connection built through the difficulties they endure together.In the end, his commanding style drives the platoon to unite around him, fostering a collective sense of purpose in spite of the initial tension.

faithfulness_original_text.text: But of course that side of the thing didn't occur to us, at first. All we knew was that he rode us hard and we hated his guts. We saw very little of our lieutenant, a plump collegiate youth who showed up periodically to insist that if we played ball with him, he would play ball with us, and even less of our company commander (I hardly remember what he looked like, except that he wore glasses). But Reece was always there, calm and contemptuous, never speaking except to give orders and never smiling except in cruelty.
anchor: But Reece was always there, calm and contemptuous, never speaking except to give orders and never smiling except in cruelty.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
He looked good. It would be too much to say that he kindled our admiration, but there is an automatic pleasure in watching a thing done well. The other platoons were clearly impressed, and although nobody in our platoon said anything, I think we were a little proud of him.

But the next period that day was close-order drill, at which the platoon sergeants had full command, and within half an hour Reece had nagged us into open resentment again.
anchor: But the next period that day was close-order drill, at which the platoon sergeants had full command, and within half an hour Reece had nagged us into open resentment again.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
* * *

Soon the change had come over the whole platoon. We were working with Reece now, instead of against him, trying instead of pretending to try. We wanted to be soldiers. The intensity of our effort must sometimes have been ludicrous, and might have caused a lesser man to suspect we were kidding—I remember earnest little choruses of "Okay, Sergeant" whenever he dispatched an order—but Reece took it all straight-faced, with that air of unlimited self-assurance that is the first requisite of good leadership. And he was as fair as he was strict, which must surely be the second requisite. In appointing provisional squad leaders, for example, he coolly passed over several men who had all but licked his shoes for recognition, and picked those he knew could hold our respect—D'Allessandro was one, and the others were equally well chosen.
anchor: The intensity of our effort must sometimes have been ludicrous, and might have caused a lesser man to suspect we were kidding—I remember earnest little choruses of "Okay, Sergeant" whenever he dispatched an order—but Reece took it all straight-faced, with that air of unlimited self-assurance that is the first requisite of good leadership.

In appointing provisional squad leaders, for example, he coolly passed over several men who had all but licked his shoes for recognition, and picked those he knew could hold our respect—D'Allessandro was one, and the others were equally well chosen.

faithfulness_original_text.text:
But if excellence is easy to admire it is hard to like, and Reece refused to make himself likable. It was his only failing, but it was a big one, for respect without affection can't last long—not, at least, where the sentimentality of adolescent minds is involved. Reece rationed kindness the way he rationed water: we might cherish each drop out of all proportion to its worth, but we never got enough or anything like enough to slake our thirst. We were delighted when he suddenly began to get our names right at roll call and when we noticed that he was taking the edge of insult off most of his reprimands, for we knew these signs to be acknowledgments of our growth as soldiers, but somehow we felt a right to expect more.

We were delighted too at the discovery that our plump lieutenant was afraid of him; we could barely hide our pleasure at the condescending look that came over Reece's face whenever the lieutenant appeared, or at the tone of the young officer's voice—uneasy, almost apologetic—when he said, "All right, Sergeant." It made us feel close to Reece in a proud soldierly alliance, and once or twice he granted us the keen compliment of a wink behind the lieutenant's back, but only once or twice.
